5.5     Accumulators Installation and Pre-Charge
The accumulators are shipped loose. Install them once the crusher main frame is 
mounted to the foundation. 
Perform the following steps for each accumulator.
1. Position the accumulator pads on the concrete pad or steel structure at the loca -
tion designated during foundation planning. Refer to 5.2.1 “Foundation” on 
page 41.
2. Anchor the pads into the foundation with post-installed anchors (not supplied 
with the crusher).
3. Attach a nylon lifting strap around the accumulator using a choker hitch. Lift the 
accumulator into position on the accumulator pad.
4. Hold the accumulator as vertical as possible, and fasten the accumulator clamp 
bracket to the accumulator.
5. Assemble the hydraulic fittings to the bottom of the accumulator.
6. Pre-charge the accumulator. Refer to 7.30 “Charging and Verifying the Accumu -
lators” on page 171.
 Figure 5-7:       Accumulator Mounting
5.6     V-Belt Drive Installation (if applicable)
5.6.1     Belt Tensioner Frame Installation on Concrete
Follow the manufacturer's recommendation for concrete surface preparation.1- Accumulator 2- Hose fittings 3- Stand
51Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 5: Installation
1. Use an epoxy grout material with the following properties:
Minimum resistance class: C20, as DIN1045-1 standard
Minimum Compression Tension: 20 MPa (2901 psi)
2. Remove all paint, primer, and rust preventative from all surfaces of the belt ten -
sioner footing.
3. Verify that the anchor bolt holes in the belt tensioner footing line up with the 
corresponding bolt holes in the foundation.
4. Remove all dirt, grease, and other foreign material from the anchor bolts.
5. Wrap three to four layers of masking tape around the straight segment of the 
anchor bolts. The tape allows the bolts to later be tensioned without damaging 
the grout.
6. Lift the anchor base high enough that the anchor bolts can be installed.
7. Insert the anchor bolts into the anchor base until the top of the bolt is 1 to 2 mm 
(0.04 to 0.08 in) above the top of the nut.
8. Place the anchor base in position on the concrete. Slide the anchor bolts into 
the grouting niches.
9. Insert supporting plates on the leveling screws so that the anchor base rests on 
the plates.
10. Level the anchor base to within +/- 1 mm (0.04 in) at the motor mounting pads, 
using the leveling screws under the base.
11. Grout the anchor bolt niches, and then wait for the grout to cure. Refer to the 
grout manufacturer’s instructions.
12. Remove the bolt-on coupling guard and idler guard from the jackshaft frame.
13. Lift the drive motor onto the anchor base.
14. Tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque designated by the civil 
planner.
15. Install the drive sheave assembly. Refer to 7.13.2 “Shaft Sheave Assembly Instal -
lation” on page 127.
Note: Mounting the drive sheave either below the countershaft or within 45 
degrees of the vertical centerline requires a change in the mounting position of 
the outer countershaft bushing oil groove. Contact FLSmidth if either of these 
mounting positions is going to be used so the bushing can be installed correctly 
prior to shipment of the crusher.
16. Install and align the crusher sheave assembly. Refer to 7.13.2 “Shaft Sheave 
Assembly Installation” on page 127.
a.  If needed, loosen the anchor bolts to adjust the sheaves until they are prop -
erly aligned. Then re-tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque.
Note: Do not install the belts at this time.
17. Verify that the anchor base is level.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
52Chapter 5: Installation
a.  As needed, loosen the anchor bolts to make adjustments until the anchor 
base is level. Then re-tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque.
18. Remove the drive motor from the anchor base and set it aside.
19. Build a dam around the anchor base to prevent the grout from leaking.
20. Wedge the anchor base into place against the concrete to prevent any move -
ment during grouting.
21. Grout the space between the anchor base and the concrete, and around the 
anchor bolt. Wait for the grout to cure. Refer to the grout manufacturer’s 
instructions.
22. Tighten the anchor bolts to the nominal required torque, as designated by the 
civil planner.
23. Install the drive side coupling if it is not already installed. Refer to the original 
equipment manufacturer (OEM) manual.
5.6.2     Belt Tensioner Frame Installation on a Steel Structure
The steel structure must be stiff enough to accept the loads with deflection limited to 
less than the acceptable misalignment condition of the flexible coupling. Refer to the 
flexible coupling instructions in the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) manual. 
1. Verify that the surface where the sole plates will be mounted is flat within 0.08 
mm/m from motor foot to motor foot. Use stainless steel shims as needed to 
level the surface.
Note: Do not use more than three shims at a maximum of 5 mm (0.2 in).
2. Remove all paint, primer, and rust preventative from all surfaces of the belt ten -
sioner footings.
3. Verify that the anchor bolt holes in the belt tensioner footings line up with the 
corresponding bolt holes in the structure.
4.  Remove all dirt, grease, and other foreign material from the anchor bolts.
5. Lift the belt tensioner frame high enough that the anchor bolts can be installed.
6. Insert the anchor bolts into the belt tensioner footings until the top of the bolt is 
1 to 2 mm (0.04 to 0.08 in) above the top of the nut.
7. Place the belt tensioner frame in position on the structure. Slide the anchor 
bolts into position, and torque the bolts to 50% of the required torque as desig -
nated by the civil planner.
8. Using stainless steel shims, level the belt tensioner frame feet to within +/- 1 mm 
(.04 in) of each other.
9. Install the drive sheave assembly. Refer to 7.13.2 “Shaft Sheave Assembly Instal -
lation” on page 127.
Note: Mounting the drive sheave either below the countershaft or within 45 
degrees of the vertical centerline requires a change in the mounting position of 
the outer countershaft bushing oil groove. Contact FLSmidth if either of these 53Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 5: Installation
mounting positions is going to be used so the bushing can be installed correctly 
prior to shipment of the crusher.
10. Install and align the crusher sheave assembly. Refer to 7.13.2 “Shaft Sheave 
Assembly Installation” on page 127.
a.  If needed, loosen the anchor bolts to adjust the sheaves until they are prop -
erly aligned. Then re-tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque.
Note: Do not install the belts at this time.
11. Tighten the anchor bolts to the final torque, as designated by the civil planner.
12. Install the drive side coupling if it is not already installed. Refer to the original 
equipment manufacturer (OEM) manual.
5.6.3     Drive Motor Installation
An electric motor weighs up to 5,200 kg (5.2 t). Handle the motor with care.
When setting up the tackle, keep it tight. Keep clear of hanging loads.
1. Install the motor side coupling if it is not already installed. Refer to the flexible 
coupling installation instructions in the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) 
manual.
2. Lift the motor onto the tensioner frame supporting pads.
3. Shim the motor to achieve the required alignment of the two coupling halves, 
and secure all the frame jackscrews. Refer to the original equipment manufac -
turer (OEM) manual.
Note: The jackshaft frame is designed for a nominal of 3.2 mm (0.13 in) shims 
beneath each motor mounting foot.
4. Torque the motor fastening bolts to 914 N-m (674 ft-lbs).
5. Remove the lifting equipment.
6. Install the electric cables in the motor’s terminal box.
7. Jog the drive motor to verify it rotates counterclockwise as viewed from the 
front of the crusher sheave.
5.6.4     V-Belts Installation
Refer to 7.12.2 “V-Belt Installation” on page 125.
5.6.5     Drive Guards Installation
Refer to drawing “661009—Overhung Crusher General Arrangement” on page 317 
when installing the drive guards.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
54Chapter 5: Installation
1. Install the coupling guard on the jackshaft frame using the provided fasteners.
2. Install the tensioner guard on the jackshaft frame using the provided fasteners.
3. Install the V-belt guard. The V-belt guard anchor bolts are not supplied by FLS -
midth.
5.7     Direct Drive Installation
5.7.1     Sole Plate Installation on Concrete
1. Prepare the concrete surface according to the manufacturer's recommendation.
2.  Select an epoxy grout material with the following properties:
Minimum resistance class: C20, as DIN1045-1 standard
Minimum compression tension: 20 MPa (2901 psi)
3. Remove all paint, primer, and rust preventative from all of the sole plate sur -
faces.
4.  Verify that the anchor bolt holes in the sole plates line up with the correspond -
ing bolt holes in the foundation.
5.  Remove all dirt, grease, and other foreign material from the anchor bolts.
6.  Wrap three to four layers of masking tape around the straight segment of the 
anchor bolts. The tape allows the bolts to later be tensioned without damaging 
the grout.
7. Lift the sole plates high enough that the anchor bolts can be installed.
8. Insert the anchor bolts into the sole plates until the top of the bolt is 1 to 2 mm 
(0.04 to 0.08 in) above the top of the nut.
9. Place the sole plate in position on the concrete. Slide the anchor bolts into the 
grouting niches.
10. Insert supporting plates under the leveling screws.
11. Install the torque limiter onto the crusher drive shaft. Refer to the original equip-
ment manufacturer (OEM) manual.
12. Remove the motor side half of the flexible coupling.
13. Install the drive shaft assembly. 
14. Apply Loctite 243, and torque the bolts in a crisscross pattern to 500 N-m (368.8 
ft-lbs).
15. Using the leveling screws, level the sole plates to within +/- 0.04 mm (1.5 mils) of 
each other. Use the drive shaft or coupling to establish a reference.
16. Grout the anchor bolt niches, and wait for the grout to cure. Refer to the grout 
manufacturer’s instructions.55Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 5: Installation
17. Lift the drive motor onto the sole plates.
18. Tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque, as designated by the 
civil planner.
19. Inspect the sole plate alignment.
20. Realign the sole plates as necessary.
a.  Remove the anchor bolt tension.
b.  Adjust the leveling screws.
c.  Tighten the anchor bolts to 50% of the required torque.
d.  Re-inspect the sole plate alignment.
e.  Repeat the sole plate realignment as needed until attaining alignment.
21. Remove the drive motor from the sole plates, and set it aside.
22. Build a dam around each sole plate to prevent the grout from leaking.
23. Wedge the sole plate into place against the concrete to prevent any movement 
during grouting.
24. Grout the space between the sole plate and the concrete, and around the 
anchor bolt. Wait for the grout to cure. Refer to the grout manufacturer’s 
instructions.
25. Tighten the anchor bolts to the nominal required torque, as designated by the 
civil planner.
5.7.2     Sole Plate Installation on Steel Structure
The steel structure must be stiff enough to accept the loads with deflection limited to 
less than the acceptable misalignment condition of the flexible coupling. Refer to the 
flexible coupling instructions in the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) manual. 
1. Verify that the surface where the sole plates will be mounted is flat within 0.08 
mm/m from motor foot to motor foot. Use stainless steel shims as needed to 
level the surface.
Note: Do not use more than three shims at a maximum of 5 mm (0.2 in).
2. Remove all paint, primer, and rust preventative from all surfaces of the sole 
plates.
3. Verify that the anchor bolt holes in the sole plates line up with the correspond -
ing bolt holes in the structure.
4. Remove all dirt, grease, and other foreign material from the anchor bolts.
5. Lift the sole plates high enough that the anchor bolts can be installed.
6. Insert the anchor bolts into the sole plates until the top of the bolt is 1 to 2 mm 
(0.04 to 0.08 in) above the top of the nut.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
56Chapter 5: Installation
7. Place the sole plate in position on the structure. Slide the anchor bolts into posi -
tion, and torque the bolts to 50% of the required torque as designated by the 
civil planner.
8. Install the torque limiter onto the crusher drive shaft. Refer to the torque limiter 
installation instructions in the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) manual.
9. Remove the drive shaft assembly ring hub and fasteners, and set it aside.
10. Install the drive shaft assembly.
11. Apply Loctite 243, and torque the bolts in a crisscross pattern to 500 N-m (368.8 
ft-lbs).
12. Using stainless steel shims, level the sole plates to within +/- 0.04 mm (1.5 mils) 
of each other. Use the drive shaft or coupling as a reference.
13. Tighten the anchor bolts to the nominal required torque, as designated by the 
civil planner.
5.7.3     Drive Motor Installation
1. Install the ring hub on the motor shaft. Refer to the flexible coupling installation 
instructions in the OEM manual.
2. Place the motor on the machined mounting pads on the sole plates.
3. Shim the motor to achieve the required alignment of the two coupling halves, 
and secure all the motor mounting.
4. Torque the motor fastening bolts to 914 N-m (674 ft-lbs).
5. Install at least two dowel pins in diagonally-opposite motor feet.
a.  Deepen the dowel holes in the motor feet by punching through to the sole 
plate.
b.  Thin the motor and sole plate holes with a reaming tool.
c.  Insert the tapered dowel pins in the holes.
6. Install the electrical cables in the motor’s terminal box.
7. Jog the drive motor to verify it rotates counterclockwise as viewed from the 
front of the crusher sheave.
8. Install the fasteners connecting the ring hub and flex hub. Torque the fasteners 
according to the instructions given in the limited end float coupling information 
in the OEM manual.
5.7.4     Drive Guards Installation
Install the drive guards. Refer to drawing “661009—Overhung Crusher General 
Arrangement” on page 317.57Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 5: Installation
5.8     Head Assembly Installation
Refer to 7.19.4 “Head Installation” on page 140.
5.9     Hydraulic System Installation
1. Place the hydraulic power unit (HPU) skid in an area that is protected from fall -
ing rock and is no more than 25 m (82 ft) from the crusher.
2. Use shims (not provided with the skid) as necessary to level the skid on the foun-
dation.
3. Bolt the skid to the foundation (bolts are not provided with the skid).
4. Disconnect the remote mounted push button panel from the HPU.
Note: The panel is pre-fixed to the HPU and is connected to the wiring terminal 
box with a multi-conductor electrical cord. It can be removed from the HPU and 
remotely mounted by changing the electrical cord.
5. Mount the remote mounted push button panel in a location that allows the 
operator to observe the crusher during clearing or while making setting adjust -
ments. The panel is pre-wired to the HPU terminal box.
Note: The supplied control panel electrical cable is 9 m (30 ft) long.
6. Connect the six hydraulic hoses to the HPU and crusher.
a.  Match the stamped markings on the HPU to the main manifold block.
b.  Shorten the hoses as needed, and reattach the reusable couplings on the cut 
end.
Note: This prevents the safety hazards caused by coiled hydraulic hoses.
c.  Connect the hydraulic hoses in the matched connections.
7. Verify the voltage, frequency, phase, and electrical connection requirements 
from the motor nameplate meet the electrical requirements.
8. Verify the hydraulic power unit pump motor rotation direction.
a.  Fully open both the tramp release and clamping circuit dump valves.
b.  Briefly start the motor. The motor must rotate counterclockwise as viewed 
from the motor end, and the arrow on top of the motor must match the rota -
tion direction.
9. Fill the tank with hydraulic fluid. Refer to A.5 “Hydraulic Oil Specifications” on 
page 193.
10. Disconnect the piping from the crusher. Either flush the lubrication pump and 
piping for approximately 10 minutes or clean out the piping with a pig before 
operating with new piping. Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
58Chapter 5: Installation
 Figure 5-8:       Hydraulic Power Unit Hose Connection
 Figure 5-9:       Release and Clearing System Hose Connections1- Clearing circuit hose connection 2- Tramp release circuit hose connection 3- Clamping circuit
4- Hydraulic motor (bowl closed) circuit 5- Hydraulic motor (bowl open) circuit 6- Hydraulic motor brake circuit
1- Clearing circuit hose connection 2- Tramp release circuit hose connection 3- Clamping circuit
4- Hydraulic motor (bowl closed) circuit 5- Hydraulic motor (bowl open) circuit 6- Hydraulic motor brake circuit
59Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19

5.10     Lubrication System Installation
5.10.1     Skid Mounted Lubrication System Installation
1. Install the lubrication system below and as near the crusher as possible.
a.  Refer to 5.10.3 “Piping Installation” on page 61 for assistance in determining 
placement.
b.  Refer to drawing “661012—Lubrication Unit General Arrangement” on 
page 325 for assistance in determining the correct placement.
2. The bottom of the reservoir must be at least 3.6 m (12 ft) below the underside 
of the crusher mounting flange to obtain the proper flow of drain oil from the 
crusher to the lubrication system reservoir. 
a.  For every 0.3 m (12 in) the lubrication system is away from the crusher hori -
zontally, the bottom of the reservoir must be at least 1.24 m (49 in) below the 
underside of the crusher mounting flange.4- A-port on hydraulic motor (close) 5-B-port on hydraulic motor (open) 6- Brake
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
60Chapter 5: Installation
 Figure 5-11:       Lubrication System Installation Location
3. Use shims (not provided with the skid) as necessary to level the package lubrica -
tion skid on the foundation.
4. Bolt the skid to the foundation (bolts are not provided with the skid).
5. Verify the voltage, frequency, phase, and electrical connection requirements 
from the motor nameplate meet the electrical requirements. 
6. Wire the pump motor. All wiring must meet site and local electrical code 
requirements.
7. Verify the direction of motor rotation by briefly starting the motor. The motor 
must rotate in the same direction as the arrow on top of the motor indicates.
8. Fill the lubrication tank. Refer to A.2 “Lubricating Oil Specifications” on 
page 188.
5.10.2     Heat Exchanger Installation
1. Install the air-to-oil heat exchanger (air cooler assembly) between the package 
lubrication system and the crusher if possible. 
Note: If the heat exchanger is installed in a lubrication room, the room needs to 
be properly vented to provide the necessary in-flow of ambient air to efficiently 
cool the oil. 
2. Place the assembly on a foundation where it is not subjected to excessive vibra -
tions.
3. Use shims (not provided with the skid) as necessary to level the heat exchanger 
on the foundation.
4. Bolt the heat exchanger to the foundation (bolts are not provided with the skid).1- Pump and motor assemblies 2- Tank 3- Crusher
4- Oil drain line 5- Horizontal and vertical distance 6- Oil supply line
62
43
1
561Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 5: Installation
5. Verify the voltage, frequency, phase, and electrical connection requirements 
from the heat exchanger motor nameplate matches the site specifications. 
6. Wire the heat exchanger motor. All wiring must meet site and local electrical 
code requirements.
7. Verify the direction of fan rotation by briefly starting the motor. The fan must 
rotate to force air through the radiator from the motor side. If the motor is 
rotating the fan in the wrong direction, change the fan motor wiring and then 
verify the direction of airflow is correct.
 Figure 5-12:       Heat Exchanger Assembly
5.10.3     Piping Installation
Refer to the drawing “661012—Lubrication Unit General Arrangement” on page 325 
for piping connection size and locations. It is recommended that the piping for the 
feed and return lines meet the following requirements:
•  Clean rust, scale, cutting chips, and debris from the piping before assembling it.
•  The slope of the return piping from the crusher to the lubrication package is 
recommended to be a minimum of 25 mm (1 in) of vertical change for every 305 
mm (12 in) of horizontal change.
•  The supply and return piping must be as direct and short as possible, with a 
minimum number of turns, dead pockets, and other obstructions.
•  Install a flexible coupling in the supply oil line and the return oil line to dampen 
the vibrations between the crusher and the remaining oil lines.
•  Install unions or bolted, flanged joints in various locations to assist in removing 
piping or lubricating equipment when required.1- Outlet 2- Fan 3- Air flow
4- Drive motor 5- Drain 6- Inlet
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
62Chapter 5: Installation
•  Avoid long vertical drops in the drain piping. Such drops create an excessive 
vacuum inside the crusher, and may cause dust to be pulled into the crusher past 
the T- and U-seals.
If a return line with a vertical drop of 1.22 m (4 ft) cannot be avoided, follow it 
with an approximately 500 mm (19.7 in) vertical rise, and then place an air 
breather in the line to break the vacuum that may otherwise result. Ensure 
that the air breather is away from any dust.
 Figure 5-13:       Air Breather Installation in Return Line
•  Supply piping must be capable of supporting the piping pressure.
5.11     Air Seal Blower Installation
1. Install the air seal blower filter away from the crusher in a relatively dust free 
area, but no more than 3.7 m (12 ft) away from the crusher.
2. Verify the voltage, frequency, phase, and electrical connection requirements 
from the pump motor nameplate matches the site specifications. 
3. Wire the pump motor. All wiring must meet site and local electrical code 
requirements.
4. Verify the direction of motor rotation by briefly starting the motor. The motor 
must rotate in the same direction as the arrows on the fan indicate.1- Air breather 2- Vertical drop 3- Vertical rise

5.12     Machine Instrumentation Package Installation
5.12.1     Countershaft Box Temperature Sensor Installation
The temperature sensor is shipped loose to avoid damage during transit.
1. Locate the temperature sensor, cover, temperature probe, mounting adapter, 
mounting clamp, and cable from one of the shipping crates. Refer to Figure 5-15  
for the proper mounting location. 
2. Remove the pipe plug from the tapped hole where the sensor will mount, and 
install the mounting adapter.
3. Slide the temperature probe into the adapter until the probe contacts the 
countershaft box bushing. 
4. Tighten the nut on the mounting adapter to secure the probe in place.
Note: Do not over-tighten the nut. This can cause damage to the probe cable.
5. Using the supplied mounting clamp, install the sensor near the crusher in an 
easily accessible area. This provides easy viewing of the local display on the sen-
sor.
6. Wire the sensor. Refer to drawing “681148— CR102 Junction Box 1 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 349 and drawing “681149—CR102 Junction Box 2 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 352.1- Turbo blower 2- Filter housing 3- 102 mm (4 in) flexible hose 4- Countershaft box
5- Crusher main frame 6- Drip shield 7- Outlet damper
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

5.12.3     Oil Supply Pressure Sensor Installation
The pressure sensor is shipped loose to avoid damage during transit.
1. Locate the pressure sensor, cover, mounting adapter, mounting clamp, and cable 
from one of the shipping crates. Refer to Figure 5-15  for the proper mounting 
location.
2. Remove the pipe plug from the tapped hole where the sensor will mount, and 
install the mounting adapter. Refer to Figure 5-15 .
3. Attach the pressure sensor to the adapter.
Note: Do not over-tighten the nut. This can cause damage to the probe cable.
4. Using the supplied mounting clamp, install the sensor near the crusher in an 
easily accessible area. This provides easy viewing of the local display on the sen-
sor.
5. Wire the sensor. Refer to drawing “681148— CR102 Junction Box 1 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 349 and drawing “681149—CR102 Junction Box 2 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 352.
5.12.4     Eccentric Bushing RTD Installation
The resistance temperature detector (RTD) is factory installed, and the cables are 
coiled and placed in the oil sump area.
1. Rout the two RTD wire leads from the oil sump area in the main frame, through 
the return line assembly, to the two cord grips. Refer to Figure 5-15 .
2. Slide the RTD wire leads through the body of the cord grips, then through the 
cord grips’ lubricated bushings, rings, and nuts.
3. Pull the slack out of the RTD wire leads.
4. Tighten the cord grips nuts to create a liquid seal.
5. Route the RTD wires to the machine I/O box.
6. Coil the excess RTD wire length in the box for later use.
7. Wire the sensor. Refer to drawing “681148— CR102 Junction Box 1 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 349 and drawing “681149—CR102 Junction Box 2 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 352.
5.12.5     Proximity Sensors
1. Install the proximity sensors in either of the indicated adjustment mechanism 
locations using the provided hardware. Refer to Figure 5-16 .
2. Verify that the mounting bracket is 20 mm (0.79 in) from the pinion.
3. Ensure that the tip of the probe is 6.5 mm (0.25 in) from the pinion tooth.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

Wiring” on page 349 and drawing “681149—CR102 Junction Box 2 Layout and 
Wiring” on page 352.

customer-provided feed arrangement, crusher throughput, and controls.

Wiring” on page 349 and drawing “681149—CR102 Junction Box 2 Layout and

5.13     Feed, Discharge, and Platform Installation
1. Install the feed arrangement (not supplied with the crusher) according to the 
site plan. Refer to 5.2.4 “Feed Arrangement Preparation” on page 42.
2. Connect a rubber skirt (not supplied with the crusher) to the source bin and set 
within the crusher hopper inside diameter. The skirt must match the dimensions 
given on drawing “661009—Overhung Crusher General Arrangement” on 
page 317.
3. Install the discharge arrangement (not supplied with the crusher) according to 
the site plan. Refer to 5.2.5 “Discharge Arrangement Preparation” on page 43.

the site plan. Refer to 5.2.6 “Maintenance Platform Preparation” on page 44.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19

72Chapter 6: Operation
6.1     Crusher Start-Up
Perform the following start-up steps every time the crusher is started.
1. Turn on the lubrication system to provide adequate lubrication to the crusher 
before turning on the crusher. Allow the lubrication system to run for at least 
one minute.
Note: In extremely cold conditions, it may be necessary to constantly run the 
heater and lubrication system to maintain the required pump start-up oil tem-
perature during long periods of down time.
2. Verify the return line oil temperature is 27° C (80° F) or warmer. Allow the lubri -
cation system to continue running until the necessary return line oil tempera -
ture is attained.
The automated control system (ACS) will energize the lubrication system 
heater as necessary to maintain the reservoir temperature at 27° to 32°C (80° 
to 90°F) as long as there is a safe oil level in the reservoir.
The ACS monitors the lubrication system faults, which have interlocks that 
would prevent the crusher from starting. Refer to 6.4.1 “Vital Sign Monitor -
ing” on page 76.
3. Visually verify the following lubrication system vital signs:
Cavity level sensor with analog inputs
Crusher drive motor starter with analog input of kW or amps (usually not pro -
vided with the crusher)
Crusher closed side setting through the proximity switch and inputs
Crushing forces through the accelerometers that monitor the adjustment ring 
lift
4. Access the inspection cover on the lubrication tank to verify lubrication oil flow.
If there is only a small stream of oil or no flow at all, do not start the crusher. 
Operating the crusher in this situation will cause extreme crusher bearing fail -
ure. Troubleshoot the issue as needed; refer to Table 8 - 5: “Lubrication System 
Troubleshooting” on page 181.
5. Start the crusher and run it empty (no-load) for five minutes.
Note: This allows the ACS to verify the proper vital signs and respond if neces -
sary.
6. Start the feed of material to the crusher, and gradually increase the feed rate 
until the choke fed conditions are reached.
7. As the feed level in the cavity approaches normal operating levels, slow the 
feeder speed to prevent it from overfilling the crusher cavity.
73Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
Note: The ACS is designed for a dual loop control program to modulate feed to 
the crusher, and to maintain both a consistent cavity level and a uniform power 
draw.
Due to design characteristics, the crusher must never be continuously oper -
ated below 50% drive motor full load amps.
6.2     Hydraulic Power Unit Start-Up
The hydraulic power unit has two modes of operation: local and remote. The selector 
switch for these two modes is located on the remote push button panel (refer to 6.8 
“Hydraulic Power Unit Remote Push Button Panel” on page 86). 
For the hydraulic power unit to operate in either mode:
1. Pull out the EMERGENCY STOP button.
2. Pull out the HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER button.
3. Press the POWER ON button to energize the hydraulic power unit control cir -
cuits. The button will illuminate when it is pushed.
With the LOCAL/REMOTE switch in the REMOTE position, the power unit is controlled 
by the control system, and all the switches on the remote push button panel are 
inoperable with the exception of the EMERGENCY STOP and the HYD. POWER UNIT 
CONTROL POWER buttons. Leave the switch in the REMOTE position during normal 
crushing operation. Refer to 6.8.15 “LOCAL/REMOTE Switch” on page 90 for a list of 
the operations that must be done in local mode.
In remote mode, the control system monitors the tramp release and clamping circuit 
pressures, and automatically pressurizes the circuits as required. Normal closed side 
setting adjustments can be made from the control system.
In both modes, the pump motor will be off and will only start if any type of hydraulic 
power unit operation is performed. Once the operation has been completed, the 
motor automatically shuts off.
The clamping circuit pressure drops to 0kPa (0 psi) during setting adjustments. When 
requested for special applications, the hydraulic power unit can be configured for 
adjusting under load. In this condition, the clamping circuit pressure drops to 1,034 
kPa (150 psi) during setting adjustments.
Circuit Pressurization Settings Tramp Release Clamping
Circuit Re-Pressurization On 11,032 kPa (1600 psi ) 17,926 kPa (2600 psi)
Low Circuit Pressure Light On 9,652 kPa (1400 psi) 16,547 kPa (2400 psi)
Table 6 - 1: Tramp Release and Clamping Power Unit Pressure Settings
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
74Chapter 6: Operation
If while operating the power unit in either mode, the red LOW TRAMP PRESSURE 
light or red LOW CLAMP PRESSURE light illuminates and the related circuit pressure 
sensor verifies a loss of pressure, the hydraulic system has likely malfunctioned.
If this occurs, immediately shut down the crusher and correct the hydraulic issue 
before restarting the crusher.
6.3     Normal Crusher Operation
The crusher is designed to only run counterclockwise as viewed from the crusher 
sheave. Do not change the crusher rotation for any reason.
Proper operation of the crusher is critical to maximize the crusher life. Operate as 
close to full power as possible without exceeding power draw peaks of 110%. 
Running at a 90% average power draw is typically necessary to avoid excessive 
power draw peaks.
Do not continuously operate the crusher at or below 50% power. 
Although far less critical, than operating at too low a power, minimize starting and 
stopping the feed in order to maximize production. However, if the crusher will not 
have feed for more than 20 minutes, it is better to shut the crusher down and then 
restart it when feed is available.
6.3.1     Setting the Crushed Product Size
The size of the crushed product is controlled by the closed side setting, which is the 
gap in the parallel zone between the mantle and the bowl liner.
Set the closed side setting to slightly less than the maximum product size required. 
6.3.1.1      Setting the Closed Side Setting Manually
Reduce the closed side setting (increase product size) by adjusting the bowl to open 
farther. The crusher setting changes 0.157 mm (0.0062 in) per drive ring tooth.
1. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch to the LOCAL position.
2. Turn the LOW SPEED/HIGH SPEED switch to the LOW SPEED position.
3. Turn the OPEN/CLOSE switch to the OPEN position.
Note: There is an initial 3 second delay while the clamp pressure automatically 
dumps.
75Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
Increase the closed side setting (decrease product size) by adjusting the bowl to close 
further.
1. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch to LOCAL.
2. Turn the LOW SPEED/HIGH SPEED switch to the LOW SPEED position.
3. Turn the OPEN/CLOSE switch to the CLOSE position.
Note: There is an initial 3 second delay while the clamp pressure automatically 
dumps.
Setting the closed side setting too tightly causes ring bounce.
 Figure 6-1:       Setting the Crushed Product Size
6.3.1.2      Setting the Closed Side Setting Through 
Automation
Before the automated control system may be used to set the closed side setting, it 
must be programmed.1- Bowl 2- Adjustment ring 3- Bowl liner
4- Parallel zone 5- Mantle 6- Head
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
76Chapter 6: Operation
Proximity sensors on the hydraulic adjust pinion count the number of teeth and 
correlate this number to a close-side-setting value. The crusher setting changes 0.157 
mm (0.0062 in) per drive ring tooth.
1. Enter the desired closed side setting in the ACS. Refer to the ACS instruction 
manual for instructions on entering the new setting.
2. The system performs the following steps without further input.
a.  The feed to the crusher stops.
b.  The crusher shuts down after the rock in the crushing cavity passes through 
it.
c.  The bowl assembly rotates closed until the bowl liner contacts the mantle.
d.  Once contact is made, the hydraulic line pressure rises, signaling the control 
system to stop the hydraulic pump.
Note: This condition is the zero setting.
e.  The bowl assembly rotates open to a programmed closed side setting.
3. During the setting adjustment, the ACS monitors the liner wear by tracking the 
difference in the zero setting from new to worn liners.
6.4     Automated Control System Operation
The crusher has an automated control system (ACS) that provides operational control 
of the crusher using vital signs and interlocks. The ACS can allow for direct operator 
control or local control through communication with the plant programmable logic 
controller (PLC) or a distributive control system (DCS).
The ACS uses a human machine interface (HMI) to display the vital signs and 
operational parameters, and allows the crusher operator to initiate the start and stop 
functions.
6.4.1     Vital Sign Monitoring
Vital sign monitoring compares the actual sensor values against minimum and 
maximum set points. Typically, there are warning set points that indicate potential 
problems and alarm set points that require immediate action.
The ACS monitors the following signals:
•  Crusher supply oil pressure
•  Crusher supply and return oil temperatures 
•  Oil filter plugged or lubrication dirty
•  Oil flow, optional
•  Lubrication tank temperature
•  Lubrication tank level
•  Heat exchanger efficiency
•  Eccentric oil temperature77Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
•  Drive motor power draw in kW or amps
•  Countershaft rpm for crusher speed and belt slip detection
•  Adjustment ring movement, or ring bounce (inputs from accelerometers)
•  Bowl creep, or turning under crushing forces
•  Clamping circuit pressure
•  Tramp release pressure
6.4.2     Interlocks
The interlocks are maintained with relay switching of the motor control voltage for 
the various electric motors associated with crusher operation.
The customer is responsible for hardwired interlocks in conjunction with the PLC 
switching interlocks for the lubrication oil pump drive motors, discharge conveyor, 
crusher, and feeder system.
The ACS is normally programmed to stop the feed to the crusher whenever a vital 
sign warning or alarm fault occurs. Feed cannot be reintroduced into the crusher until 
the warning or fault is resolved.
The following interlocks allow the crusher to be started:
•  Lubrication pump is operating and has been running for two minutes
•  Proper supply oil temperature
•  Proper return oil temperature
•  Adequate oil level in the lubrication oil reservoir
•  Proper supply oil pressure
•  No lubrication alarm faults with the vital sign monitor
The following interlocks allow feed to be introduced to the crusher:
•  Discharge conveyor operating
•  Proper clamp and tramp circuit pressure
•  No vital sign warnings
6.5     Performing a Clearing Cycle for Inspection
1. De-energize the main drive motor and lock it out, following the site lock-out tag-
out procedures.
2. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the LOCAL position.
3. Turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. 
Hold the switch until the adjustment ring reaches the limit of travel (approxi -
mately 30 seconds).
Note: This will depressurize the tramp release cylinders, and pressurize the 
clearing circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
78Chapter 6: Operation
4. While holding the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position, 
place safety blocks between the adjustment ring and the main frame at the main 
frame pin locations. Do not seat the safety blocks on the main frame bushing. 
Refer to Figure 6-2 "Safety Blocking" on page 80.
While placing the safety blocks, continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position. If the switch is released, the adjust -
ment ring and bowl will lower.
5. Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR selector switch. This will allow the 
adjustment ring and bowl assemblies to lower onto the safety blocks. 
6. Inspect the desired components. Refer to 7.8.1 “Determining the Main Frame 
Seat Liner Wear” on page 116.
7. Once the inspection is complete, turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/
CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. This will depressurize the tramp release cyl -
inders, and pressurize the clearing circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring 
and bowl assemblies.
8. Remove the safety blocks.
9. Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to allow the adjustment ring 
and bowl to lower back onto the main frame.
10. Visually verify that the adjustment ring and bowl have properly seated back onto 
the main frame. If they have not, perform the above steps again.
Never pressurize the tramp release cylinders if the adjustment ring is not sit -
ting level on the main frame. 
Doing so will damage the tramp release system components, main frame, and 
adjustment ring.
11. Reset the tramp release system pressure. Refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp 
Release System Pressure” on page 86.
12. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the REMOTE position.
13. Unlock the main drive motor and re-energize it.
6.6     Clearing Lodged Material
If the crusher stops while crushing (under load), do not attempt to restart it with the 
crushing cavity full of material. Trying to restart the crusher with a full crushing cavity 
will severely damage the machine and drive motor.
The crusher may stop during a crushing cycle for a number of reasons, including:
•  Power bumps or outages
•  Operating too close to the motor control limits, causing the motor to shut down
79Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
•  Rapid loss of oil pressure, causing an emergency shutdown
•  Crushed product buildup under the crusher
•  Tramp material too large for the tramp release system to pass
•  Improper belt tension, causing slipping or burned drive belt
Inform all personnel in the area that the crusher is about to be cleared. Verify that 
no one is near the adjustment ring.
6.6.1     Clearing Rock from the Crusher 
1. De-energize the main drive motor and lock it out, following the site lock-out tag-
out procedures.
2. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the LOCAL position.
3. Turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. 
Hold the switch until the adjustment ring reaches the limit of travel (approxi -
mately 30 seconds).
Note: This will depressurize the tramp release cylinders, and pressurize the 
clearing circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.  Usu -
ally with the crushing cavity enlarged by raising the adjustment ring and bowl 
assemblies, material trapped in the crusher will be dislodged. 
4. If the material in the crushing cavity is too large to slide out of the crusher:
a.  Continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR 
position.
b.  Place safety blocks between the adjustment ring and the main frame at the 
main frame pin locations. Do not seat the safety blocks on the main frame 
bushing.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
80Chapter 6: Operation
While placing the safety blocks, continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position. If the switch is released, the 
adjustment ring and bowl will lower.
 Figure 6-2:       Safety Blocking
c.  Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR selector switch. This will allow 
the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies to lower onto the safety blocks. 
d.  With the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies resting securely on the safety 
blocks, stand on the adjustment ring and deflect the rubber skirt that seals 
the bottom of the feed chute and the rock hopper in the bowl assembly. 
e.  Remove any material that was too large to pass through the cavity with a long 
bar.1- Adjustment ring 2- Safety block 3- Main frame 4- Main frame bushing
81Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
Do not attempt to remove any material from the crushing cavity unless the 
equipment is locked out and safety blocks have been placed between the 
main frame and the adjustment ring to hold the ring in a raised position.
The safety blocks will protect hands and arms from being caught between 
the crushing members.
Never place feet or hands between the main frame and the adjustment 
ring, even when the safety blocks are in place.
f.  Once all material has been cleared, turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. This will depressurize the tramp 
release cylinders, and pressurize the clearing circuit, which will raise the 
adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.
g.  Remove the safety blocks.
5. Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to allow the adjustment ring 
and bowl to lower back onto the main frame.
6. Visually verify that the adjustment ring and bowl have properly seated back 
onto the main frame. If they have not, perform the above steps again to finish 
cleaning out the crusher.
Never pressurize the tramp release cylinders if the adjustment ring is not sit -
ting level on the main frame, whether due to the safety blocks or material left 
in the crusher. 
Doing so will damage the tramp release system components, main frame, and 
adjustment ring.
7. Reset the tramp release system pressure. Refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp 
Release System Pressure” on page 86.
8. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the REMOTE position.
9. Unlock the main drive motor and re-energize it.
6.6.2     Clearing Tramp Metal From the Crusher
A piece of tramp metal that is too large to pass through the crusher may become 
jammed during crushing.
1. De-energize the main drive motor and lock it out, following the site lock-out tag-
out procedures.
2. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the LOCAL position.
3. Turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. 
Hold the switch until the adjustment ring reaches the limit of travel (approxi -
mately 30 seconds).
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
82Chapter 6: Operation
Note: This will depressurize the tramp release cylinders, and pressurize the 
clearing circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.  Usu -
ally with the crushing cavity enlarged by raising the adjustment ring and bowl 
assemblies, material trapped in the crusher will be dislodged. 
4. If all of the material is removed from the crushing cavity:
a.  Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch. The adjustment ring and 
bowl will lower back into the frame.
b.  Visually verify that the adjustment ring and bowl have properly seated back 
onto the main frame. If they have not, perform the above steps again to finish 
cleaning out the crusher.
Never pressurize the tramp release cylinders if the adjustment ring is not 
sitting level on the main frame, whether due to the safety blocks or material 
left in the crusher. 
Doing so will damage the tramp release system components, main frame, 
and adjustment ring.
c.  Reset the tramp release system pressure. Refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp 
Release System Pressure” on page 86.
d.  Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push 
button panel to the REMOTE position.
e.  Unlock the main drive motor and re-energize it.
5. If the material in the crushing cavity is too large to slide out of the crusher:
a.  Continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR 
position.
b.  Place safety blocks between the adjustment ring and the main frame at the 
main frame pin locations. Do not seat the safety blocks on the main frame 
bushing.
While placing the safety blocks, continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position. If the switch is released, the 
adjustment ring and bowl will lower.
c.  Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR selector switch. This will allow 
the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies to lower onto the safety blocks. 
Refer to Figure 6-2 "Safety Blocking" on page 80.
d.  With the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies resting securely on the safety 
blocks, remove the rubber skirt that seals the bottom of the feed chute and 
the rock hopper in the bowl assembly.
83Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
The stored energy in the steel crusher components may be applying signifi -
cant force on the tramp metal. Removing tramp metal can be very danger -
ous because metal can be expelled from the crushing cavity with enough 
velocity to do bodily harm.
e.  Determine the method that is most likely to be the safest for removing the 
tramp metal.
The first method is to use an overhead lifting device to pull the tramp 
metal out of the crusher. Refer to 6.6.2.1 “Removing Metal With an Over -
head Lifting Device” on page 83.
The second method is to burn the metal out of the crusher. Refer to 
6.6.2.2 “Burning Metal From the Crusher” on page 84.
Both methods present some danger because a person has to have a clear 
view of the jammed metal in the crushing cavity. The metal will normally 
shoot upward toward the head feed plate. Carefully follow all given instruc -
tions for the chosen method.
6.6.2.1      Removing Metal With an Overhead Lifting Device
1. Perform all steps in 6.6.2 “Clearing Tramp Metal From the Crusher” on page 81.
2. Turn off the hydraulic power unit and lock it out according to site policy.
3. Use a long pole or rod to slip a hook or sling around the tramp metal.
4. Connect the free end of the hook or sling to an overhead lifting device.
5. Verify all personnel are standing to the side and away from the crusher.
The metal is most likely to shoot upward toward the head feed plate; standing 
aside at 90 degrees from the metal is necessary to remain outside the path of 
the metal.
6. Once the metal is loose in the cavity, pull it out. The metal will be hot.
7. Unlock and re-energize the crusher drive motor once the cavity is clear.
8. Unlock and re-energize the hydraulic power unit.
9. Turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. 
This will depressurize the tramp release cylinders, and pressurize the clearing 
circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
84Chapter 6: Operation
While removing the safety blocks, continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position. If the switch is released, the adjust -
ment ring and bowl will lower.
10. Remove the safety blocks.
11. Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to allow the adjustment ring 
and bowl to lower back onto the main frame.
12. Visually verify that the adjustment ring and bowl have properly seated back onto 
the main frame. If they have not, perform the above steps again to finish clean -
ing out the crusher.
Never pressurize the tramp release cylinders if the adjustment ring is not sit -
ting level on the main frame, whether due to the safety blocks or material left 
in the crusher. 
Doing so will damage the tramp release system components, main frame, and 
adjustment ring.
13. Reset the tramp release system pressure. Refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp 
Release System Pressure” on page 86.
14. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the REMOTE position.
15. Monitor the crusher closely, paying particular attention to the oil temperature, 
oil pressure, and unusual sounds. If anything is out of the ordinary, shut down 
the crusher for a maintenance inspection and repairs.
6.6.2.2      Burning Metal From the Crusher
1. Perform all steps in 6.6.2 “Clearing Tramp Metal From the Crusher” on page 81.
2. Turn off the hydraulic power unit and lock it out according to site policy.
3. Use a long pole or rod to slip a hook or sling around the tramp metal.
4. Connect the free end of the hook or sling to an overhead lifting device.
5. Secure a hot work permit from the appropriate site management. Follow all site 
policies and procedures.
6. Protect the discharge conveyor and any other flammable materials in the 
crusher discharge area.
7. Stand to the side of the crusher, approximately 90 degrees to the jammed metal.
85Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
The metal is most likely to shoot upward toward the head feed plate; standing 
aside at 90 degrees from the metal is necessary to remain outside the path of 
the metal.
8. Burn the metal. Work on the narrowest section of the metal possible without 
burning into the manganese steel liners.
9. Burn slowly to allow the metal to collapse on itself.
10. Once the metal is loose in the cavity, attempt to push it through or pull it out. 
The metal will be hot.
11. Unlock and re-energize the crusher drive motor once the cavity is clear.
12. Unlock and re-energize the hydraulic power unit.
13. Turn and hold the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to the CLEAR position. 
This will depressurize the tramp release cylinders, and pressurize the clearing 
circuit, which will raise the adjustment ring and bowl assemblies.
While removing the safety blocks, continue holding the TRAMP PRESSURE 
RESET/CLEAR switch in the CLEAR position. If the switch is released, the adjust -
ment ring and bowl will lower.
14. Remove the safety blocks.
15. Release the TRAMP PRESSURE RESET/CLEAR switch to allow the adjustment ring 
and bowl to lower back onto the main frame.
16. Visually verify that the adjustment ring and bowl have properly seated back 
onto the main frame. If they have not, perform the above steps again to finish 
cleaning out the crusher.
Never pressurize the tramp release cylinders if the adjustment ring is not sit -
ting level on the main frame, whether due to the safety blocks or material left 
in the crusher. 
Doing so will damage the tramp release system components, main frame, and 
adjustment ring.
17. Reset the tramp release system pressure. Refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp 
Release System Pressure” on page 86.
18. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE switch on the hydraulic power unit remote push but -
ton panel to the REMOTE position.
19. Monitor the crusher closely, paying particular attention to the oil temperature, 
oil pressure, and unusual sounds. If anything is out of the ordinary, shut down 
the crusher for a maintenance inspection and repairs.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
86Chapter 6: Operation
6.7     Resetting the Tramp Release System Pressure
1. Verify that the accumulator is charged. Refer to 7.30 “Charging and Verifying the 
Accumulators” on page 171. Pressurizing the accumulator without first charging 
it damages the bladder, requiring replacement.
2. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE selector switch at the remote mounted push button 
panel to the LOCAL position.
3. Close the tramp release circuit dump valve.
4. Turn the RESET TRAMP PRESSURE/CLEAR selector switch to RESET TRAMP PRES -
SURE, which will make the tramp release circuit automatically re-pressurize.
5. Verify that the LOW TRAMP PRESSURE light turns off.
Note: The tramp release circuit will not pressurize after a clearing cycle until the 
selector switch is momentarily turned to RESET TRAMP PRESSURE. This reset 
mode is to keep the tramp release circuit from accidentally being pressurized 
while the safety blocks are still in place.
6. Turn the LOCAL/REMOTE selector switch to the REMOTE position and resume 
normal operation.
7. Monitor the oil level sight gauge, and add oil as required.
6.8     Hydraulic Power Unit Remote Push Button Panel
Pressing the machine power button on the remote push button panel only turns off 
the electric power to the controls. Use caution when troubleshooting the power 
unit or making any adjustments. Always lock out the main power supply and the 
electrical controls before servicing the power unit and the crusher.
Note: The control panel lights illuminate when the set points are reached. For the set 
points, refer to H.1 “TR1000-0008—Control Logic Operating Statement” on page 448.
87Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
 Figure 6-3:       Hydraulic Power Unit Push Button Controls
6.8.1     EMERGENCY STOP Button
Press the EMERGENCY STOP button to de-energize the power unit control circuit. The 
light in the green POWER ON button will turn off. This will shut down all motors, 
pumps, and electrical circuits. 
Use caution when troubleshooting or performing any power unit adjustments. 
Electrical power will still be present at some of the terminals even with the 
EMERGENCY STOP button pushed in the off position.
Lock out the hydraulic power unit and controls at the energy sources before 
performing work on the machinery.
Pull the EMERGENCY STOP button to re-engerize the panel. The green POWER ON 
light will illuminate after this button and the HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER 
button are both pulled, indicating that the control circuit has been activated. This will 
not restart the motors or pumps. These must be restarted individually from the 
control panel. See the following sections. 
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
88Chapter 6: Operation
6.8.2     HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER Button
Verify that the EMERGENCY STOP button is pulled out, then pull the HYD. POWER 
UNIT CONTROL POWER button to activate the hydraulic circuit.
6.8.3     Green POWER ON Button and Light
The light in the POWER ON button illuminates when the EMERGENCY STOP button 
and the HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER button are pulled out, and then the 
POWER ON button is pressed. The light indicates the activation of the hydraulic unit 
control circuit.
Note: If an E-stop condition prevents power from being restored to the system, press -
ing the POWER ON button will not power the circuit.
The light in the POWER ON button turns off when the EMERGENCY STOP button or 
the HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER button is pressed.
6.8.4     Amber SERVICE MODE Light
The SERVICE MODE light illuminates when the OPERATION/SERVICE hydraulic power 
unit selector switch is set in the SERVICE position. The light will be off during normal 
operations.
6.8.5     Red LOW TRAMP PRESSURE Light
The LOW TRAMP PRESSURE light illuminates when the tramp release circuit pressure 
falls below 96.5 bars (1400 psi).
Note: The tramp release circuit automatic pressurization occurs at 110.3 bars (1600 
psi).
The light turns on during cleaning.
6.8.6     Red LOW CLAMP PRESSURE Light
The LOW CLAMP PRESSURE light illuminates when the clamping circuit pressure falls 
below 165.5 bars (2400 psi).
Note: The clamping circuit automatic pressurization occurs at 179.2 bars (2600 psi).
The light turns on when opening or closing the bowl setting.
6.8.7     Blue REMOTE Light
The REMOTE light illuminates when the LOCAL/REMOTE switch is turned to the 
REMOTE position, indicating that control of the hydraulic power unit (including closed 
side setting adjustments) can only be made from the control system. No control of 89Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
the hydraulic power unit is possible at the local mounted control panel when the 
selector switch is in the REMOTE position.
6.8.8     Red DIRTY FILTER WARNING Light
The DIRTY FILTER WARNING light illuminates when the oil filter cartridge is dirty and 
must be replaced.
6.8.9     Red SYSTEM HIGH TEMPERATURE WARNING Light
The SYSTEM HIGH TEMPERATURE WARNING light illuminates when the tank oil 
temperature is too high.
6.8.10     Red BOWL DRIVE PRESSURE WARNING Light
The BOWL DRIVE PRESSURE WARNING light illuminates when the contact is made 
between the mantle and bowl liner during liner calibration. It also indicates when 
resistance or an obstruction prevents the bowl assembly from rotating in the closed 
direction.
6.8.11     Red OIL LEVEL WARNING Light
The OIL LEVEL WARNING light illuminates when the HPU oil level is low.
6.8.12     OPEN/CLOSE Switch
Turn the OPEN/CLOSE switch to the OPEN position to turn the bowl 
counterclockwise, and to increase the closed side setting. 
Conversely, turn the switch to the CLOSE position to turn the bowl assembly 
clockwise, and to decrease the closed side setting.
6.8.13     LOW SPEED/HIGH SPEED Switch
The LOW SPEED/HIGH SPEED switch controls the speed of the bowl adjust motor. 
The HIGH SPEED position is used primarily for bowl installation and removal. 
The LOW SPEED position is typically used for adjusting the closed side setting. Do not 
adjust the closed side setting while the switch is in the HIGH SPEED position.
6.8.14     RESET TRAMP PRESSURE/CLEAR Switch
When the RESET TRAMP PRESSURE/CLEAR switch is in the CLEAR position, the tramp 
release cylinders are dumped to zero and the hydraulic pump motor starts to send oil 
to the clearing circuit. The adjustment ring with bowl assembly rises, opening a gap Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
90Chapter 6: Operation
between the bowl liner and the mantle on the head assembly. The maximum clearing 
stroke is 150.4 mm (5.92 in). Refer to 6.6 “Clearing Lodged Material” on page 78 for 
information on how to clear out the crusher.
When crusher clearing is complete, remove any safety blocks that were inserted 
during clearing and turn the switch to the RESET TRAMP PRESSURE position. This 
action pressurizes the tramp release circuit.
6.8.15     LOCAL/REMOTE Switch
Leave the LOCAL/REMOTE switch in the REMOTE position unless performing any of 
the local functions at the control panel. In REMOTE position, none of the switches on 
the remote push button panel are operable except for the EMERGENCY STOP and the 
HYD. POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER buttons.
With this selector switch in the LOCAL position, the following operations can be 
conducted at the remote mounted push button panel:
•  Turn the bowl in or out for setting adjustments and for bowl removal and 
installation (refer to 6.3.1 “Setting the Crushed Product Size” on page 74).
•  Clear the crushing cavity, followed by resetting the automatic pressurization of 
the tramp release control circuit (refer to 6.6 “Clearing Lodged Material” on 
page 78).
•  Reset the tramp pressure (refer to 6.7 “Resetting the Tramp Release System 
Pressure” on page 86.
•  Change the adjustment motor speed (refer to 6.8.13 “LOW SPEED/HIGH SPEED 
Switch” on page 89).
6.9     Hydraulic Power Unit Service Switches
The two hydraulic power unit service switches are located on the side of the electrical 
terminal box, inside the hydraulic power unit.
The switches provide the ability to troubleshoot the tramp release and clamping 
systems from the hydraulic power unit without the need to operate the controls on 
the remote push button panel.91Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 6: Operation
 Figure 6-4:       Power Unit Service Switches
6.9.1     OPERATION/SERVICE Switch
Set the OPERATION/SERVICE switch in the OPERATION position during normal 
operations. In this position, the TRAMP/OFF/CLAMP switch is disabled and the amber 
SERVICE MODE light on the remote push button panel is off. Automatic pressurization 
of the clamping and tramp release circuits by the control system is enabled.
Turning the switch to the SERVICE position for the ability to manually pressurize the 
tramp release and clamping circuit pressures. This switch position illuminates the 
amber SERVICE MODE light on the remote push button panel. The automatic 
pressurization feature of the control system is disabled during this time.
6.9.2     TRAMP/OFF/CLAMP Switch
The TRAMP/OFF/CLAMP switch is a spring return-to-center selector switch. The 
OPERATION/SERVICE switch must be in the SERVICE position for this switch to 
function.
Hold the TRAMP/OFF/CLAMP switch in the TRAMP position to manually pressurize 
the tramp release circuit.
Hold the switch in the CLAMP position to manually pressurize the clamping circuit.
6.10     Shutdown
1. Shut the feed off to the crusher and allow the crusher to run empty for five min-
utes.
2. Turn the power off to the crusher drive motor and monitor the time it takes for 
the crusher to coast to a stop. Coast-down time will be 60 to 90 seconds.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
92Chapter 6: Operation
Note: The ACS monitors the coast down time and logs the data.
3. Under normal operating oil temperatures, allow the lubrication system to run an 
additional five minutes before shutting down.
4. If the return oil temperature is in a warning or alarm condition, continue operat -
ing the lubrication system until the temperature drops to within the normal 
operating temperature range.
5. In extremely cold conditions, if the crusher will not be down for more than four 
hours leave the lubrication system running if possible.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

7.22.1 Upper Head Bushing Removal  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 152

96Chapter 7: Maintenance
7.1     Maintenance Overview
This chapter provides detailed information on maintaining the equipment and its 
systems safely and efficiently. Regular care and maintenance must be performed as 
outlined in this chapter.
For maintenance instructions specific to an accessory piece of equipment (item which 
is furnished by FLSmidth but is fabricated by a third party) refer to the original 
equipment manufacturer documentation. 
Do not install, operate, maintain, or repair this equipment unless you have read and 
understand the instructions and warnings in Chapter 1: “Safety” on page 1. Failure 
to follow these safety precautions could result in personal injury, death, or property 
damage.
7.1.1     Welding and Weld Repair of Major Castings
The main frame, bowl, head, and adjustment ring are critical components in the 
function of the crusher. These specific parts are cast using high alloy steel that has 
special welding requirements. Before doing any welding on these specific parts, a 
certified welder must submit a weld procedure specification (WPS) to FLSmidth 
engineering for review. The failure to provide a WPS for review voids the crusher 
warranty.
7.1.2     Introduction
Exercise great care while performing maintenance to avoid damaging the crusher 
components.
Take the following precautions when working on the crusher:
•  Handle parts with care if they have bearings, or machined or journal surfaces. 
These parts are either designed to close tolerances or are critical surfaces.
Do not allow these parts to contact hard surfaces. Support the parts on 
wooden blocking or rubber mats.
Do not install any part that has a bearing or journal surface without first coat -
ing it with oil.
•  Handle and install bronze bushings with great care.
Bronze is soft; ramming or pounding a bushing during installation may cause 
distortion or other damage.
97Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 7: Maintenance
•  Coat mating parts that have either a press or sliding fit with light oil to prevent 
rusting in place.
•  Thoroughly clean and oil any machined parts prior to installation.
7.1.3     Thermal Process for Removal and Installation
Thermal procedures are required for the removal and subsequent installation of 
some components.
•  The components can be damaged by improper heating techniques. Whenever 
possible, heat the components in an oil bath, temperature-controlled oven, or 
induction heater.
•  Establishing a uniform, soaking heat of the minimum temperature necessary. 
•  Do not use cutting torches as a heating tool. Concentrated heat from a cutting 
torch will result in hot spots that may cause dimensional distortions or cause 
residual stress concentrations and can adversely surface harden parts. Excessive 
localized heating can cause stress cracks.
•  Oxygen acetylene or oxygen propane torches are not recommended; only use 
these torches if it is the only method available, and only with great care. Use a 
burner tip that provides a diffused flame if the torch is used.
•  If flame heating of gearing must be used, avoid direct flame contact with the 
hardened surfaces. Instead, warm the bore and internal faces, and allow the 
heat to slowly soak to the outside.
•  Do not exceed the provided target temperature. Overheating can damage parts 
by affecting the metallurgy and causing residual stress concentrations.
•  Apply heat rapidly and evenly when heating parts for removal, and then remove 
the part as quickly as possible to minimize heat transfer to the mating part.
•  Do not quench parts in liquid to cool them. If fast cooling is required, limit the 
cooling speed to that which can be attained with a fan or compressed air 
stream.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
