cycle all hydraulic circuits to verify 
that there are no leaks.6.8 “Hydraulic Power 
Unit Remote Push 
Button Panel” on 
page 86

component fasteners are secure.
Verify that the mantle does not 
touch the bowl liner.6.3.1 “Setting the 
Crushed Product Size” 
on page 74
Verify that the equipment feeding 
the crusher is functioning properly.

(Commissioner)                                               (Date)
_________________________________   _________________
(FLSmidth Service Representative)              (Date)
C.2     No-Load Inspection
Perform the initial pre-start-up inspection before performing the no-load inspection.
Run the crusher without a load for at least two hours to complete the no-load run. 
Rebuilt crushers may require a longer no-load run to allow the new bushings to 
conform to the old journal surfaces.
Note: In very cold climates, it may be necessary to perform the no-load run until the 
return oil temperature reaches 27°C (80°F). During the run, perform the following 
inspection. 
Commissioning Step Reference Commissioner 
Sign-OffFLSmidth Service Rep 
Sign-Off
Verify the lubrication oil drain line 
temperature is above 27°C (80°F).
Inspect for lubrication oil and 
hydraulic oil leaks.
Verify the head spin speed is within 
an acceptable range.
Record the crusher speed [(motor 
sheave diameter)/(crusher sheave 
diameter)] × motor rpm = crusher 
rpm
Record the crusher drive motor no-
load amps.
Record the temperature at which the 
lubrication unit mounted relief valve 
stopped bypassing.
Verify the crusher has run with no 
load for two hours without any 
issues.
Record the coast-down time.
Table C-2: No-Load InspectionCopyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

C.3     65% of Full Load Inspection
Perform the no-load inspection before performing the 65% of full load inspection.
Run the crusher with 65% of a full load for two hours to complete the run. At the end 
of the run, perform the following inspection. 
_________________________________   _________________

the center of the feed plate, and the 
feed distribution is adequate.
Verify that the crusher ran at 65% of 
full load for two hours without any 
issues.

C.5     Full-Load Inspection
Perform the 80% of full load inspection before performing the eight hours of full-load 
inspection.
Run the crusher with a full load for eight hours to complete the run. At the end of the 
run, perform the following inspection. 
Commissioning Step Reference Commissioner 
Sign-OffFLSmidth Service Rep 
Sign-Off
Verify that the feed material is hitting 
the center of the feed plate, and the 
feed distribution is adequate.
Verify that the tramp release and 
clamping circuit pressures hold 
without re-pressurizing more than 
eight times an hour after the system 
stabilizes from the initial 
commissioning.
Record the full-load amps from the 
crusher drive motor nameplate.
Record the lubrication oil return line 
temperature.
Record whether the fan is on or off at 
the time the temperature is taken.
Record the supply oil temperature.
Record whether the fan is on or off at 
the time the temperature is taken.
Record the eccentric supply oil 
pressure.
Record the socket liner supply oil 
pressure.
Record the closed side setting.

212Appendix D: Maintenance Schedule
D.1     Maintenance Schedule
To keep the crusher in a good operating condition, schedule daily, weekly, monthly, 
and yearly inspections with a written log of what was done and found. Repairs can be 
made in advance to avoid major breakdowns.
D.1.1    Daily Maintenance
Maintenance Operation Comments and References Completed
Verify the hydraulic oil tank level.
Read the lubrication oil pressure at the crusher. A.2 “Lubricating Oil Specifications” on 
page 188
Take the oil inlet temperature at the crusher. Normal condition: 38° to 54°C (100°F to 
130°F)
Verify the cavity level and power draw. 6.3 “Normal Crusher Operation” on 
page 74
Normal condition: 1.4-2.8 bar (20-40 
psi)
Verify the closed side setting. 6.3.1.2 “Setting the Closed Side Setting 
Through Automation” on page 75
Inspect the oil piping for leaks.
Verify the tramp release circuit pressure. 7.29.1 “Pressurizing the Tramp Release 
System Manually” on page 168
Normal condition: 124 bars (1800 psi)
Verify the clamping circuit pressure. 7.29.3 “Pressurizing the Clamping 
System Manually” on page 170
Normal condition: 193 bars (2800 psi)
Verify the clamping circuit accumulator pre-charge 
pressure.7.30 “Charging and Verifying the 
Accumulators” on page 171
Normal condition: 69 bars +/- 3 bars 
(1000 +/- 50 psi)
Verify the feed distribution in crushing cavity. 5.2.4 “Feed Arrangement Preparation” 
on page 42
Inspect the crusher discharge area to ensure it is 
clear and the discharge conveyor is running 
properly.
Inspect the main frame arms for material buildup.
Take the crusher coast-down time. Normal condition: 60 to 90 seconds
Inspect for any loose fasteners.
Inspect for any unusual noises.
Determine the remaining liner life. 7.8.1 “Determining the Main Frame 
Seat Liner Wear” on page 116
Table D-1: Daily Maintenance213Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix D: Maintenance Schedule
D.1.2    Weekly MaintenanceInspect the adjustment ring for movement.
Inspect the oil tank strainer basket under the 
inspection cover in the lubrication tank for debris 
and drain line oil flow.7.26 “Oil Strainer Basket Replacement 
(Lubrication Unit)” on page 167
Maintenance Operation Comments/References Completed
Inspect the condition of the air seal blower filter. 7.14 “Air Seal Blower Maintenance” on 
page 130
Inspect the condition of the lubrication and 
hydraulic power unit tank breathers. Replace dirty 
breathers; they are not cleanable.
Ensure dust and debris is not built up around the 
lubrication system breather.
Inspect the V-belts for tightness and alignment. 7.12.3 “V-Belt Tensioning” on page 126
Table D-2: Weekly MaintenanceMaintenance Operation Comments and References Completed
Table D-1: Daily MaintenanceCopyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
214Appendix D: Maintenance Schedule
D.1.3    Monthly Maintenance
D.1.4    Annual MaintenanceMaintenance Operation Comments/References Completed
Inspect the engagement of the adjust motor pinion 
teeth with the drive ring teeth.7.10.2 “Drive Ring Installation” on 
page 121
Inspect and lubricate the adjust motor according to 
the manufacturer's specifications.
Have the lubrication and hydraulic oils analyzed; 
change the oil if required.A.4 “Lubricating Oil Contamination” on 
page 192
Verify the countershaft end float. Advanced maintenance manual 
(available from FLSmidth)
Normal condition: 0.51 to 0.64 mm 
(0.002 to 0.025 in).
If the closed side setting has not changed more 
than one inch, turn the bowl in and out a few 
times.6.3.1 “Setting the Crushed Product Size” 
on page 74
Inspect for cracked, loose, or worn liners.
Verify the tramp release circuit accumulator pre-
charge pressure. Verify the pre-charge monthly for 
new or repaired accumulators.7.30 “Charging and Verifying the 
Accumulators” on page 171
Normal condition: 103 +/- 3 bars (1500 
+/- 50 psi)
Inspect the feed plate, bowl liner, and mantle for 
wear and tightness.
Ensure the adjustment ring threads are lubricated 
with the bowl unclamped; use the recommended 
grease.7.3 “Thread Wear Inspection” on 
page 104
Clean the heat exchanger to remove the dust and 
dirt buildup in the core.
Table D-3: Monthly Maintenance
Maintenance Operation Comments/References Completed
Completely disassemble the crusher. Inspect all 
bearing surfaces and the gear and pinion contact 
for wear.Chapter 7: “Maintenance” on page 93
Inspect the main frame, head, and bowl for signs of 
fatigue cracking.
Inspect all piping and fasteners for tightness.
Inspect the fit of the main shaft in the main frame 
bore.
Table D-4: Annual Maintenance215Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix D: Maintenance Schedule
D.1.5    At Liner Change Maintenance
Maintenance Operation Comments/References Completed
Inspect and re-condition the seating surfaces on 
the bowl and head if necessary.
Inspect the head bushing, head ball, socket liner, 
eccentric, and dust shell for wear.
Inspect the head locking nut and feed plate for 
wear; replace if required.
Inspect the main frame liners, arm guards, 
countershaft box guards, and counterweight guard 
for wear, and recondition if necessary.
Inspect for thread galling and wear on the bowl, 
adjustment ring, and clamping ring.

390Appendix G: Drawing Package
G.31     RXL1302-5001—Adjustment Ring Assembly 
/T36/T79/T79/T3/T90/T72/T76/T74/T75/T87/T86/T3/T68/T85/T72/T3/T76/T81/T3

402Appendix G: Drawing Package
G.40     RXL1007-5005—Socket Assembly 
/T36/T79/T79/T3/T90/T72/T76/T74/T75/T87/T86/T3/T68/T85/T72/T3/T76/T81

1 
 The control logic for the Raptor 1100 Cone Crushers  is explained throughout this document.  The 
control logic is required to operate the Rapt or 1100 Cone Crusher at its highest efficiency.

5 II. Crusher 
A. Bowl Adjustment 
Two proximity switches, located near one of  the adjustment drive pinions, monitor the 
direction of rotation of the bo wl assembly and are used to calculate the CSS (Closed Side 
Setting).  Each gear tooth represents 0.016 in. [0.40 mm] of  CSS adjustment.  
1.  Bowl Creep 
If the bowl assembly turns two or more teeth in  either direction during operation, defined 
by existence of full clamp pressure 2, 600 psi [17.9 MPa], a “Bowl Creep Alarm” 
notification should be displayed and feed to the crusher should be stopped.  
Start
PT1 > 2,600 psi
CSS = Count - 2RESET
CSS = 2 + Count
Display
AlarmStop Feed
to CrusherCSS = CountSend Alarm to

NoYes
Yes
YesYes

6 2. Tooth Counting Process 
The tooth counting process employs inductive proximity sensors that monitor the pinion 
teeth.  The two proximity sensors are slight ly skewed to detect rotational direction and 
count.  When both proximity sensor signals are off, the tooth count is reset.  This method 
will allow partial contact at the beginn ing of an adjustment or bowl creep.

7 
 3. Calibration 
The calibration procedure has two different options: Physical CSS measurement or metal-
to-metal liner contact. 
a. Slug Method – CSS Measurement 
The CSS is physically measured and the value is then entered into the HMI. 
b. Metal-to-Metal Contact Method (Recommended) 
This method uses contact between the liner as semblies to zero the CSS.  A pressure 
switch is used to measure the hydraulic pressure.  The cont rol system closes the bowl 
with the lube running while the crusher driv e motor is off.  Upon contact, the pressure 
increases to approximately 750 psi [5.2 MPa] and stops the bowl from closing.  The 
CSS is set to zero.  The bowl opens to the last registered CSS using the t ooth count. 
 Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

4. Bowl Open Low Speed  
The bowl open for manual adjustment procedure is completed on the remote pushbutton 
box located on the HPU or on the automation HMI.   
a. Manual  
The control to the remote pushbutton box is allowed by SS3 to LOCA L.  Once SS3 is in 
LOCAL, the operator may adju st the crusher with the SS1 selector switch.  The brakes 
are pressurized on the hydraulic adjust mo tors and are released when pressure is 
applied.  Clamp pressure is released during a 5 second delay.  Once the brakes are pressurized and the timer is finished, th e motors are pressurized.  Once SS1 is 
returned to center (3-way Selector) the sy stem will normalize itself to operating 
pressure. 457Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix H: Automation

b. Automation 
The bowl open for auto adjustment procedur e is completed on th e automation HMI.  
The control on the remote pushbutton st ation SS3 must be set to remote for 
automation adjustment.  Input from the HMI runs the same sequence as the manual 
adjustment.  The input must be maintained on the HMI.  Release will cause the system 
to normalize. Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19

 5. Bowl Close Low Speed 
The bowl close manual adjustment procedure is completed on the remote pushbutton box 
located on the HPU or on the automation HMI.   
a. Manual 
The control to the remote push button box is allowe d by SS3 to LOCAL.  The operator 
may adjust the crusher with th e SS1 selector switch.  The brakes are pressurized on the 
hydraulic adjust motors and are released wh en pressure is applied.  Clamp pressure is 
released during a five second delay.  Once  the brakes are pressurized and the timer is 
finished, the motors may be pressurized. Once SS1 is returned  to center (3-way 
Selector) the system will normalize  itself to operating pressure. Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19

16 
 B.  Countershaft Bushing Temperature 
A temperature sensor, mounted in the count ershaft box, monitors the countershaft bushing 
temperature. If the bushing temperature reaches 120°F [49 /g113C], a “High Countershaft Bushing 
Temperature Alarm” notification should be disp layed. If the bushing temperature reaches 
130°F [54 /g113C], a “High Countershaft Bushing Temper ature Warning” notification should be 
displayed and feed to the crusher should be st opped.  There is a 10 minute delay after the 
alarm is reset. 
 
Note:   FLSmidth recommends that  the customer evaluate the operating tem perature after 
several months and reset the warning to 10 /g113F [12 /g113C] above the normal operating temperature. 
Maximum allowable temperature is 185 /g113F [85 /g113C]. 
 
TT6 > 120°F
TT6 > 130°F
RESETStart
General
Warning
Stop Feed to
CrusherGeneral
WarningNo
No
YesYesYes

17 
 C.  Countershaft Box Blower  
The countershaft box blower is required to keep  a positive pressure inside the crusher and 
prevent dust from entering throu gh the seals.  The blower is  started at the same time as the 
lube pump.  If the blower stops while the crusher is running, a “Countershaft Box Blower 
Warning” notification should be displayed.  There is no interlock with the crusher, but the 
blower should be addressed as soon as possible. 
 
START
Lube Pump M03 = 1
B L 1=0
RESETGeneral
WarningNo
Yes
Yes
YesNo
No
 
 
 
 Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19

18 D.  Crusher Speed 
A proximity sensor mounted to the countershaft bo x assembly monitors the speed of the direct 
drive assembly or crusher sheave. 
1. Clutch Slip If the speed of the torque-limiting clutch is le ss than 30% of the n ormal crusher operating 
speed for ten seconds, a “Clutch Slip Alarm – Crusher Shutdown” notification should be 
displayed, feed to the crusher should be stopped, and the crusher motor should be shut 
down. 
ZS3 < 0.30*NS for
10 SecStartGeneral
AlarmStop Feed to
Crusher
Stop Crusher
Drive MotorNoYes
End
 
2. Belt Slip 
If the speed of the crusher sheave is less th an 95% of the normal crusher operating speed 
for three seconds, a “Belt Slip Warning” notificati on should be displayed.  If this condition 
continues for 10 seconds, a “Belt Slip Al arm – Feed Shutdown” notification should be 
displayed and feed to the crusher should be  stopped.  If the condition persists for 20 
seconds, a “Belt Slip Alarm – Crusher Shutdo wn” notification should be displayed and the 
crusher motor should be shut down. 467Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix H: Automation
TR1000-0008—Control Logic Operating (Sheet 20) 
 TR1000-0008 Revision: 
Page:  06

3. Coast Down Time: 
Every time the crusher drive motor is shut down, coast down time (total seconds from 
running speed until five RPM) is recorded to monitor crusher conditions.  If the coast down 
time is less than or equal to 90% of the pr eviously recorded coast down time, a “Coast 
Down Time Warning” notification should be displayed.  There is no interlock with the 
crusher, but the condition should be addressed as soon as possible.

20 E.  Drive Motor 
The Raptor 1100 Cone Crusher is driven by an electric motor that  is rated for a power draw of 
1,000 HP [746 kW].  The lubrication pump must run for a minimum of two minutes prior to 
starting the crusher drive motor.  A hard wire safety interlock between the lube pump and the 
crusher drive motor should not allow the crusher drive motor to  start without the lubrication 
pump running.  If the lubrication pump mot or is stopped, the crusher drive motor must be 
stopped immediately.

TR1000-0008—Control Logic Operating (Sheet 22) 
 TR1000-0008 Revision: 
Page:  06 
21 of 46 
Control Logic Operating Statement  
This document is Confidential and Proprietary to FLSmi dth. Unauthorized use or reproduction without written permission is strictly prohibited 
 
21 
 I. Feed Setting Control 
A critical function of the automation system is to determine the appropriate feed rate to the 
crusher for optimum performance and safe operatio n.  The feed control is integrated with a 
crusher CSS adjustment (Closed Side Setting se t point), measurement of  the cavity level 
(cavity level set point), measurement of the powe r draw (power draw set point), and crushing 
force via vibration monitoring for adjustment ring movement (vibration sensor alarm set 
points).  The Control Engineer can  be most effective in developing a feed control with a full 
understanding of how these items interrelate for a specific application. 
1. Initial Feed Rate 
The initial feed rate should be accelerated to a level above the normal feed rate control set point in order to rapidly fill the cavity to a safe semi-choke fe d condition.  An undesirable 
semi-choke fed condition will be evident in the readings of the vibration sensors. The vibration sensors will typically show an increa se in vibration until the crusher reaches a 
safe semi-choke fed condition, at which point,  the vibration drops to the desired normal 
operating levels. 
2. Cavity Level Control 
The crusher controller provides the desired feed rate set point (F
SP) to the plant-wide 
automation system that control s the supply of feed to th e crusher as the manipulated 
variable (F MV).   The F SP is determined by the measurement of cavity level (CLM) relative to 
the cavity level set point (CL SP) which generally is level in the chamber that ensures a 
choke fed cavity (full crushing chamber).  In general, most Raptor 1100  Cone Crushers will 
be operated in a choke fed condition; howe ver, there are exceptions such as low feed 
conditions or high reduction ratio conditio ns where either crushing force or power 
consumption are the primary conc erns.   Once a crusher is choke fed, the feed rate set 
point is manipulated to maintain a choke fed co ndition over a controllable level span that is 
impacted by transport and control lags.  A feed er directly above the crusher is preferred, 
but suitable control can be achieved with transport  lags up to 30 to 40 seconds, provided 
the crusher hopper permits a large control span for the CLM.   
3. Power Control 
Power control for a Cone Crusher can be ac complished under choke fed or non-choke fed 
conditions.  A choke fed condition power control is preferable for the safe operation of the 
Cone Crusher, and is also sometimes referr ed to as hybrid level / power control mode Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
470Appendix H: Automation
TR1000-0008—Control Logic Operating (Sheet 23) 
 TR1000-0008 Revision: 
Page:  06 
22 of 46 
Control Logic Operating Statement  
This document is Confidential and Proprietary to FLSmi dth. Unauthorized use or reproduction without written permission is strictly prohibited 
 
22 
 because both CLM and power draw measurements ma y alternatively define the F SP.  For 
example, in a high power draw choke fed oper ation, the crusher wi ll consume the highest 
power per ton in the undesirable semi-choke fed condition.  Prior to achieving a safe CLM, 
the power consumption may exceed  the power draw set point.  During this time, the cavity 
level control loop must remain the dominant determinant of feed rate even though the 
measured power draw may be above t he desired set point.  Once the CL SP is achieved, if 
the power draw is below the desired power dr aw set point, the power draw control loop 
becomes dominant until a cavity level alarm co ndition shifts control to the cavity level 
control loop.  The CL SP can be increased by the crusher controller in order to maintain 
operation above the minimum power consumption set point. 
A pure power control mode (operation without a CLM) is accomplished by choosing a power 
draw set point, which is typically 90% of the full load motor rating or 1300 HP [970 kW], 
and adjusting the feed rate until this powe r consumption rate is  achieved within an 
acceptable dead band of acceptable power consumption.  The vibration sensors must be closely monitored to ensure that undesirable adjustment ring movement is not occurring 
due to poor feed conditions or a closed side setting that is too tight.  Frequent adjustment 
ring movement alarms require correction of the underlying root causes, which may include 
such things as: feed segregation, poor feed  distribution, excessive fine feed and/or 
moisture in the feed, too fine a feed for the crushing chamber, or a too tight closed side 
setting.  An unresolved tramp material situatio n can also be a cause of severe adjustment 
ring movement.  All adjustment ring movement  is undesirable as it creates excessive 
crushing forces which will severely shorten the li fe of critical components.  Critical to the 
success of any Cone Crusher is  the proper crushing chamber  for the feed and operating 
conditions.  The Raptor
® Cone Crushers do not have to be choke fed, nor are they severely 
limited to minimum feed rates, provided an appropriate crushing chamber is used and the 
crusher is operated under appropriate feed  conditions (free of excessive fines and 
moisture, uniform distribution of feed, etc.) 
4. Crusher Setting Control 
Crusher setting control is an integral part of a successful automated feed control plan.  
Under the hybrid power / level control, freq uent, but not continuous adjustment of the 
setting will be required to optimize the productivity of the machine.  The frequency of adjustment can be once every two to three hour s in high power draw applications.  More 471Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix H: Automation
TR1000-0008—Control Logic Operating (Sheet 24) 
 TR1000-0008 Revision: 
Page:  06 
23 of 46 
Control Logic Operating Statement  
This document is Confidential and Proprietary to FLSmi dth. Unauthorized use or reproduction without written permission is strictly prohibited 
 
23 
 commonly, setting adjustment is only required once in a wo rk shift.  If the crusher is 
unable to maintain power draw control and re mains in constant cavit y level control, then 
the crusher may be configured  to automatically close the se tting (four to 10 adjustment 
ring teeth).  The crusher controller adjusts th e closed side setting if a minimum power 
draw level cannot be achieved at the maximum CL SP (which, as stated earlier, can be 
continuously increased in order to maintain power consumption above the minimum level).  
A setting adjustment is executed once the feed is interrupted and power consumption 
drops to an indicated no-load operational level.   After adjustment, the feeder will restart 
and proceed through the normal feed start and control cycles. If excessive vibration 
occurs, then it is assu med that the excessive vibration is a result of closing the setting too 
much.  The feed is interrupted and the crusher se tting is opened (advised to be 50% of the 
closed setting adjustment) once the power consumption drops to an indicated no-load 
operational level.    
5. Minimum Power Draw Setting 
The minimum power draw setting is a user-def ined setting that signals when the cavity 
level set point must be increased or the crusher setting may be adjusted. 
6. Minimum Desired Feed Rate The minimum desired feed rate is the feed ra te which achieves an operation condition that 
avoids low cavity or unloaded cavity crushing.  A rapid oscillating inlet lubricating oil 
pressure is indicative of an underfed Cone Cr usher.  If such a condition is frequent or 
unavoidable, then it is strongly advised th at the crusher chamber be modified for the 
safest operation of the crushe r under the conditions of an  underfed Cone Crusher. 
7. Uneven Distribution Of The Crushing Load Excessive crushing with too coarse of a chamber will result in an uneven distribution of crushing load.  The contact pattern on the head bushing and eccentric will show 
predominant wear at the bottom.  It is prefer able to see an even distribution of load on 
these components.  This can be accomplished wi th better feed control and proper selection 
of a crushing chamber for the application.  Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.

24 
 G.  Vibration 
Four vibration sensors are mounted to the bottom of the drive ring retainers to monitor 
adjustment ring bounce.  Warning set points must be defined at the commissioning of the crusher.  This is done by creating a limited am ount of ring bounce by adjusting the closed side 
setting and observing the values of the Vibrat ion Sensors while crushing.  When ring bounce 
occurs, select the highest value (VTx) and use 90% of that value as the warning set point.  
When this level of ring bounce is detecte d during operation, a “Ring Bounce Warning” 
notification should be displayed.  If any of the vibration sensors exceed the warning level set 
point for a period of 15 second s, if there is a minimum of 10 occurrences in a three second 
minimum, or continuous signal within a four minute period, a “Ring Bounce Alarm” notification should be displayed.  Feed to the cru sher should be shut down, and the CSS should 
automatically open five adjustment ring teeth.

26 III. Lubrication – NOTE: All set points are based  on the use of ISO 150 Oil  
A. Filter Differential Pressure 
A pressure differential sensor monitors pressure drop across the in-use filter when the lube 
tank temperature is greater than 90 /g113F [32 /g113C].  If the differential pressure between the two 
streams reaches 35 psi [240 kPa], a “Lube Oil Dirty Filter Warning” notification should be displayed.  If the differential pressure re aches 45 psi [275 kPa] a “Lube Oil Plugged Filter 
Warning” notification should be disp layed.  After the system has been reset, a timer begins to 
prevent repeated alarms.  There is  no interlock with the crushe r for any of these warnings, but 
the lube filter should be add ressed as soon as possible.

27 B. Lube Oil Supply Pressure 
A pressure sensor, mounted in the supply line near the crusher, monitors the crusher oil 
supply. The crusher drive motor is not allowed to start if the oil pressure is below 20 psi [140 
kPa].  During operation, if the pressure drops to 17 psi [115 kPa], a “Low Supply Oil Pressure 
Alarm” notification should be displayed and feed to the crusher should be stopped.  If the 
pressure drops to 13 psi [90 kPa], an “Extre me Low Oil Supply Pressure Alarm” notification 
should be displayed and the crusher drive motor sh ould shut down.  If the pressure drops to 5 
psi [35 kPa] for 5 seconds, an emergency shutdown sequence should be initiated, including a lube pump shutdown to prevent o il spillage. The crusher drive mo tor cannot be restarted until 
the supply pressure reaches 20 psi [140 kPa].

and

28 
 C. Drain / Supply Oil Temperature  
1.  High / Low Oil Temperature 
A temperature sensor, mounted on the underside of the drain pipe to the tank, monitors the 
crusher drain line temperature.  A separate  temperature sensor, mou nted after the air or 
water cooler(s), monitors the cr usher supply line temperature.  If the supply line oil 
temperature drops to 68 /g113F [20 /g113C] while the crusher is running, a “Low Supply Oil 
Temperature Warning” notification should be displayed.  If the drain line temperature 
reaches 130 /g113F [55 /g113C], a “High Drain Oil Temperature Warning” notification should be 
displayed.  If the drain line temperature reaches 135 /g113F [57 /g113C], a “High Drain Oil 
Temperature Alarm” notification should be di splayed and feed to the crusher should be 
stopped.  If the drain line temper ature does not drop below 130 /g113F [55 /g113C] after five minutes, 
a “Continuous High Dr ain Oil Temperature Al arm” notification should be displayed and the 
crusher drive motor should shut down.  The crusher drive motor will also shut down if the 
drain line temperature reaches 140 /g113F [60 /g113C], and a “Drain Line Extreme High Oil 
Temperature Alarm” notification should be displayed. 
 
The drain line temperature cont rols the oil-to-air type coolin g system. The oil-to-air cooled 
system typically consists of two radiator-type co olers. To maximize the efficiency of this 
system, the coolers should be “ stepped” on and off as follows: 
/g131 Air Cooler #1 motor on @ 110 /g113F [43 /g113C] 
/g131 Air Cooler #2 motor on @ 115 /g113F [46 /g113C] 
/g131 Air Cooler #2 motor off @ 105 /g113F [41 /g113C] 
/g131 Air Cooler #1 motor off @ 100 /g113F [38 /g113C] 
The oil-to-water cooled system typically consi sts of two tube and shell coolers with a non-
electrical water control valve that maintains the required oil temperature to the crusher. 477Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix H: Automation

temperature difference continues for 10 minut es, a “Continuous High Differential Lube Oil

 D.  Eccentric Bushing Oil Temperature 
1. Differential 
A temperature sensor is located in the lower thrust bearing to monitor oil temperature 
between the eccentric bushing and the main  shaft.  If the oil temperature reaches 54 /g113F 
[30 /g113C] above the Crusher drain line temp erature, a “High Eccentric Bushing 
Temperature Alarm” notification should be displayed and feed to the crusher should be stopped.  If the alarm continues for one minut e, or if the temperature difference reaches 
100/g113F [55 /g113C], an “Extreme Eccentric Bushing Temperature Alarm” notification should be 
displayed and the crusher drive motor should be shut down.

 2. Bushing Temperature 
The RTD temperature sensor located in the lower thrust bearing to monitor oil 
temperature between the eccentric bushing an d the main shaft.  If the oil temperature 
reaches 167 /g113F [75 /g113C] “High Eccentric Bushing Temperature Warning” notification should 
be displayed and feed to the crusher should be stopped.  If the warning continues for 
three minutes, or if the temperature difference reaches 194 /g113F [90 /g113C], an “Extreme 
Eccentric Bushing Temperature Alarm” notifi cation should be displayed and the crusher 
drive motor should be shut down. 
Note:  Set point temperatures to  be confirmed on-site.

 E. Lubrication System 
1. Oil Level  
The lubrication system tank is equipped with a low oil level switch.  If the lube oil drops 
below the minimum oil level, a “Lube Tank Low Oil Level Alarm” notification should be 
displayed, feed to the Crusher should be sto pped, and after one minute, the crusher drive 
motor will shut down.  The lube tank imme rsion heaters will either shut down, or be 
prevented from starting, and the lube pump motor will be shut down two minutes after the 
crusher drive motor shuts down.

 2. Oil Tank Temperature 
A temperature sensor monitors th e oil temperature in the lube oil tank.  Immersion heaters 
in the lube tank turn on at 86 /g113F [30 /g113C] and turn off at 95 /g113F [35 /g113C].  The oil temperature 
must be a minimum of 80 /g113F [15 /g113C] before the lube pump  motor can be started.

 IV. Hydraulic System 
A.  Oil Level 
The hydraulic power unit tank is equipped with  high level and low level switches.  If the 
hydraulic oil drops below the minimum oil level, a “Hydrauli c Power Unit Low Oil Level 
Warning” notification should be displayed an d the pump motor cannot be started.  If the 
hydraulic oil is above the maximum oil level, a “High Hydraulic Oil Level Warning” notification 
should be displayed.  There are no interlocks with the crusher, but the oil level should be 
corrected in the reservoir to avoid oil spillage during a clearing operation.

 B.  Oil Temperature 
A temperature sensor, mounted in the hydr aulic oil tank, monitors the hydraulic oil 
temperature.  If the hydraulic oil reaches 150 /g113F [65 /g113C], a “Hydraulic Power Unit High Oil 
Temperature Alarm” notification should be displ ayed.  The hydraulic pump motor should be 
shut down and remain disabled until the temperature has dropped to 145 /g113F [63 /g113C].

38 
 D. Pressure  
Pressure sensors monitor the clamp and tramp ci rcuit pressures in the hydraulic power unit. 
1.  Tramp Release 
If the tramp circuit release pressure drops below 1,600 psi [11.0 MPa], the hydraulic pump 
motor will start and pressurize the system to  1,800 psi [12.4 MPa].  If the tramp circuit 
release pressure drops below 1,400 psi [9.6 MPa]  or the pressure remains below 1,600 psi 
for 5 minutes, a “Tramp Circuit Low Rele ase Pressure Alarm” notification should be 
displayed and feed to the crusher should be stopped.   
Start
PT2 < 1,600 psi1,400 psi > PT2PT2 > 1,800 psiPT2 < 1,600 psi
De Energize
SV9Energize
SV1Energize
SV9Start

SV1

 2.  Clamp 
If the clamp circuit pressure drops below 2,600 psi [17.9 MPa], the hydraulic pump motor 
will start and pressurize the clamp circuit back  to 2,800 psi [19.3 MPa].  If the clamp circuit 
pressure drops below 2,400 psi [16.5 MPa] or the pressure remains below 2,600 psi for 3 
minutes, a “Low Clamp Circuit Pressure Alar m” notification should be displayed and feed to 
the crusher should be stopped.

 3.  System Pressure 
If the hydraulic system trie s to pressurize 10 or more times in a one hour 
period during automatic re-pressurization or the pump continues to re-
pressurize for 5 minutes, a “Hydraulic Power Unit Excessive Pressurization 
Warning” notification should be displ ayed and the pump motor should be 
shut down.

 4. Clear (Manual operation without any interlocks) 
This operation is completed to clea r the crusher chamber with the main 
crusher motor off. The cycle is initiated to lift the crusher adjustment 
assembly off the main frame to allow material to evacuate the chamber. This is a remote operation at the cr usher there is no available operation 
through the automation interface. Th e auto-repressurization cycle for the 
tramp system should be disabled. 
Start SS3 Local = 0 SS2 Clear = 1
SS2 Clear = 0Start

 5. Tramp Pressure Reset (After manual clearing)  
This operation is completed after a clea ring cycle. The cycle is initiated 
after the crusher adjustment assembly has come to rest on the main 
frame. There is no interlock to preven t pressurization prior to this. This is 
a remote operation at the crusher there is no reset through the automation interface. Once the tramp pressure is reset, the system should 
restart the auto repressuizati on of the tramp system. 
 
Start SS3 Local = 0 SS2 Reset = 1
PT2 = 2,600 psiStart Motor
M01 = 1
De Energize SV1 De Energize SV9Stop Motor
M01 = 0Energize SV1 Energize SV9

 6. Tramp Pressure Service Mode  
This operation is completed for maintenance and troubleshooting 
purposes. This is a remote operation at the crusher hydraulic unit there is 
no operation through the automation interface. Once the operation is 
complete the system should continue to monitor tramp pressure. 
Start SS3 Local = 0 SS5 Service = 1 SS4 Tramp = 1

2Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
1.1     Crusher Main Frame Description
The main frame, which is typically bolted to a foundation, provides a rigid support for 
the crusher components, while transmitting the crushing force to the foundation.
To protect the inside of the frame from wear, main frame liners are welded to the 
frame, and arm guards protect the three arms of the frame.
The main shaft is secured in the main frame hub with an interference fit. The 
eccentric assembly rotates around the fixed main shaft. The socket assembly is 
mounted on the top of the main shaft, and supports the head assembly.
A thrust bearing is bolted to the top of the main frame hub, and supports the rotating 
eccentric assembly. Shims located under the thrust bearing can be inserted or 
removed, and are used to adjust the position of the gear and pinion relative to one 
another.
Pins mounted in the adjustment ring match up with holes in the main frame bushings, 
and prevent the adjustment ring from turning during crushing. The pins also serve as 
guides to properly re-seat the adjustment ring on the main frame following the 
passing of tramp material.
Mounted around the top of the main frame gear well is a replaceable U-shaped seal. 
This seal, with its mating T-shaped seal in the eccentric assembly, forms a labyrinth to 
prevent oil leaking from the crusher, and dust from entering the crusher.
1.1.1     Main Frame Ring
The main frame ring is a replaceable wear ring that is press fit into the inner bore of 
the main frame, and supports the pinion end of the countershaft box assembly . This 
machined ring eliminates the need for expensive rework of the inner main frame bore 
where wear is normally experienced due to the working between the countershaft 
box and the main frame. 
1.1.2     Tramp Release
Hydraulic tramp release cylinders hold the adjustment ring to the main frame during 
crushing. They also lift the adjustment ring and bowl assembly from the main frame 
during clearing. The actual force employed by the cylinders is determined by the 
hydraulic pressure applied to the tramp release cylinders; hydraulic pressure forces 
the barrel down during crushing and upward during clearing. The piston and piston 
rod remain fixed during both operations.
When crushing forces exceed the tramp release forces, the hydraulic oil is displaced 
through a pressure relief valve from the bottom side of the cylinder to the top side as 
well as to the accumulators. This allows the adjustment ring to lift, and tramp 
material to pass through the crusher. Whenever the adjustment ring lifts, the barrel 
has to pivot slightly. This motion is accommodated by a spherical washer with mating 
spherical surfaces in the top of the adjustment ring flange.
One end of each hydraulic cylinder is connected to the adjustment ring with a hex 
nut, and the other end is attached to the main frame with a pin. A non-crushable item 
(tramp) that is passing through the crushing cavity causes a crusher overload, which 3Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
in turn causes the adjustment ring to lift off the frame. The ring lift extends the 
cylinder, and forces oil from the rod side of the cylinder to an accumulator which is 
mounted on the main frame. This oil compresses the pre-charged nitrogen gas in the 
accumulator. When the tramp has passed through the crushing cavity and the 
crusher overload condition has passed, the compressed nitrogen in the accumulator 
forces the oil back into the tramp release cylinders. This retracts the tramp release 
cylinders, and re-seats the adjustment ring on the main frame.
If for any reason the crusher stops with rock in the crushing cavity, the cylinders can 
be extended, lifting the adjustment ring and bowl assembly off the main frame to 
open the crushing cavity enough to clear the crusher. This is accomplished by 
depressurizing the rod side of all the tramp release cylinders, and pressurizing the 
piston side.
 Figure 1-1:       Tramp Release, Clamping, and Clearing Cylinders
1.1.3     Clamping Cylinders
Clamping cylinders are mounted in the clamping ring, and position it above the 
adjustment ring. The clamping ring contains threads on its inner diameter. When the 
clamping cylinders are pressurized, the clamping ring lifts slightly and locks the bowl 
assembly in place. This prevents the bowl from turning during crushing.
The dust shell and an integral seal are bolted to the top of the adjustment ring. The 
dust shell and its seal protect the clamping ring, clamping cylinders, and bowl threads 
from dust and dirt.1- Clamping ring 2- Clamping cylinder 3- Adjustment ring
4- Tramp cylinder 5- Clearing cylinder
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
4Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
1.1.4     Clearing Circuit
The clearing circuit is a system of hydraulic cylinders (shared with the tramp release 
circuit) that lift the adjustment ring when they are energized. The system lifts until it 
is dead-headed, and can operate up to the maximum hydraulic power unit pressure of 
207 bars (3000 psi).
The clearing circuit cannot be energized until the tramp release circuit is de-
pressurized and an open channel is made for the oil to displace from the tramp 
release cylinders during the clearing cycle. The system pressure transducer monitors 
the pressure in the clearing circuit.
1.1.5     Open and Close Bowl Adjustment Circuits
The hydraulic power unit (HPU) provides a flow of oil under pressure to the hydraulic 
drive assemblies such as the motors, gear reducers, and brake. When opening or 
closing the bowl, the circuits operate with the lower flow of one of two stacked 
pumps in the power unit. However, when the bowl is completely removed or 
installed, both stacked pumps run to increase the speed of the process.
The oil makes a complete circuit through the hydraulic motors, and then flows back to 
the HPU reservoir. There is no pressure or flow monitored in the open or close bowl 
adjustment circuits.
When either the close or open bowl adjustment circuit is actuated, a bi-directional 
valve sends the oil flow in the appropriate direction to screw or unscrew the threaded 
bowl assembly into or out of the adjustment ring.
1.1.6     Adjustment Ring Assembly
The adjustment ring assembly is made up of the adjustment ring with welded 
mounting brackets for the hydraulic adjust motors, clamp ring and clamp cylinders 
with interconnecting hoses, dust shell with seal, and fasteners.
The adjustment ring sits on the conical surface of the frame, and has threads on its 
inside diameter. The threads provide the means for turning the bowl assembly into 
and out of the crusher. They also allow for adjustments to the crusher closed side 
setting. 5Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
 Figure 1-2:       Main Frame, Adjustment Ring, and Tramp Release Assemblies
1.2     Drive Description
The drive motor must be a squirrel cage induction motor  with 600 horsepower, and 
rated for continuous duty. It must have a normal starting torque of approximately 
125% and a normal breakdown torque of approximately 200%, within +/-10% 
acceptable voltage variance. It is recommended that the crusher be equipped with a 
reduced voltage starter.
An electric motor with a 1.15 service factor is required to maintain a continuous 
horsepower level. If a service factor of 1.0 is used, reduce the planned operating 
horsepower by approximately 15%; this will significantly reduce the crusher 
performance.
Use stator thermostats and abrasive resistant insulation. TEFC motors are more 
durable in abrasive applications, but the motor used may be open drip proof or 
enclosed fan cooled.
1.2.1     Direct Drive
If using a direct drive motor, the motor must be designed to handle the vibration, 
axial thrusting, and peak torques that can occur in this type of operation. Have the 
motor supplier contact FLSmidth regarding gear mesh frequency and RPMs for motor 1- Main frame 2- Adjustment ring 3- Clamping ring 4- Clamping cylinder
5- Dust shell 6- Dust shell seal 7- Main shaft 8- Lower U-seal
9- Arm guard 10- Main frame liner 11- Tramp cylinder 12- Fulcrum bar
13- Seat liners 14- Lower thrust bearing
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
6Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
design. Selection of the coupling joining the motor to the crusher requires special 
consideration, as it will be exposed to shock and vibration.
1.2.2     V-Belt Drive
The crusher is driven with a set of 16 8V-belts. They reduce the load shocks being 
transmitted to the crusher drive motor. Various combinations of sheave diameters are 
used to change the speed of the countershaft to fit different application 
requirements. There are two types of belts available: single and banded.
 Figure 1-3:       V-Belt Drive
Either type of belt can be used on a standard sheave. The advantage of banded belts 
is that they reduce the chance of rollover or belt whip.
With the use of a V-belt drive, the following considerations must be addressed when 
ordering the motor:
•  Motor bearings must be sized to handle overhung loads for the sheave and belt 
pull
•  The motor is to have 360° radial belt pull capacity
•  The motor shaft diameter must be able to withstand peak torque and 
simultaneous bending due to belt pull and sheave weight
•  The motor shaft must be a proper length to accommodate the motor sheave 
bushing or hub, and also provide clearance between the motor housing and the 
rim of the sheave
1.2.3     Jackshaft Drive
In order to transmit the required 447 kW (600 horsepower) and allow for power 
surges, very high tensioning forces must be applied to the drive belts. This would 
require an expensive drive motor with a special shaft and bearings to handle this load 
if the crusher driving sheave was mounted directly to the motor shaft. To reduce 
motor cost and increase reliability, the crusher can be supplied with a belt tensioner 
arrangement, in which the driving sheave is mounted on a shaft that is supported in 
the two roller bearings, and the shaft is coupled directly to the motor.
The drive motor and jackshaft assembly includes a V-belt tensioning idler pulley 
arrangement.
The belt tensioner assembly provides a unique arrangement for setting and 
maintaining proper belt tension. An idler pulley applies force to the top of the V-belts 
on the slack side (opposite from the pulling side). This force increases the wrap on the 
drive sheave (smaller sheave), and maintains uniform tension to the drive belts. The 
force is achieved through two lever arms and coil springs compressed to a specific 1- Single belt 2- Banded belt
1 27Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
setting. The increased wrap on the drive sheaves significantly reduces the belt 
tension necessary to transmit the horse power, resulting in increased countershaft 
bushing and jackshaft bearing life.
 Figure 1-4:       Belt Tensioner Configuration
1.3     Countershaft and Sheave Description
An electric motor transmits power to the countershaft with a set of V-belts or direct 
drive equipment. The countershaft has a bevel pinion gear mounted on one end, and 
it drives a gear that is mounted on the underside of the eccentric assembly. 
Two bronze sleeve bushings that are inserted in each end of the countershaft box 
support the countershaft. Dowels in the countershaft box prevent any rotation of the 
bushings in the bores. The bushing flange absorbs thrust loads from the pinion and 
the oil flinger. 
An oil flinger is pressed onto the drive end of the countershaft. The centrifugal force 
of the rotating oil flinger prevents oil from leaking past the drive end bushing. This oil 
then collects in the end of the countershaft box, and drains back to the crusher sump 
area through a passage in the box. A piston ring oil seal is held in place by a tight fit in 
the cover. The piston ring groove in the oil flinger forms a labyrinth seal, and rotates 
around the piston ring to keep oil from leaking past the running clearance between 
the countershaft and cover bore.
The countershaft box is held in the main frame by a set of capscrews around the 
outer flange. An O-ring and wear ring located on the pinion end of the countershaft 
box mate with surfaces on the frame ring. A guard mounted on the countershaft box 
protects it from wearing due to the falling material in the crusher.
An analog temperature sensor is mounted near the countershaft box to measure the 
outer box bushing temperature. The control system monitors the sensor, and the 
system signals and alarm when the temperature rises above the 54°C (130°F) 
setpoint.1- Crusher sheave 2- Idler pulley 3- Motor sheave 4- Drive motor
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
8Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
 Figure 1-5:       Countershaft Box Assembly
1.4     Eccentric Assembly Description
The eccentric has a tilted and out-of-round outside diameter, and it rotates around 
the main shaft, which is fixed in the main frame. The eccentric functions like a cam to 
produce the eccentric motion. The head has a bore that matches the outside 
diameter of the eccentric, and follows an elliptical path as the eccentric is rotated. A 
bronze bushing is locked in the eccentric bore; it provides a bearing for the main 
shaft. A bevel gear that is driven by the countershaft pinion is bolted to the bottom of 
the eccentric. The eccentric assembly rests on a set of thrust bearings. 
The rotating bronze upper thrust bearing is bolted to the bottom of the eccentric, 
with the fixed steel lower thrust bearing bolted to the main frame. Shims are placed 
between the lower thrust bearing and the main frame to adjust the backlash between 
the eccentric gear and the countershaft pinion. The eccentric has a bolted 
counterweight that has a heavy side and a light side. The heavy side of the 
counterweight is located opposite the heavy side of the eccentric to reduce the 
unbalanced forces associated with the rotating eccentric and head assemblies. 
The outside of the counterweight has a bolted guard to protect it from wear caused 
by the discharge material. Replaceable U- and T-shaped seals are mounted around 
the top and bottom of the counterweight. These seals, along with adjoining seals in 
the head and main frame, form a labyrinth to prevent dust from entering the crusher 
and oil from leaking out.1- Pinion 2- Countershaft 3- Oil flinger
4- Cover 5- Outer countershaft bushing 6- Inner countershaft bushing
7- Countershaft box 8- Piston ring seal 9- Temperature probe location
9Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
 Figure 1-6:       Counterweight Assembly
1.5     Socket Assembly Description
The socket assembly consists of a socket and dowel pins that have an interference fit 
on the main shaft, and a bronze socket liner that has a slight interference fit on the 
socket.
The socket assembly provides a spherical bearing surface on which the head gyrates 
during the crushing activities.
The socket assembly transfers the crushing force to the main frame. The socket is 
held in place on the main shaft by a press fit and a series of bolts. The socket liner, 
which is mounted and doweled in a counter bore of the socket, provides a bearing 
surface for the head ball. Pressurized lubricating oil is supplied to the grooves located 
in the spherical surface of the socket liner to provide lubrication between the socket 
liner and head ball.
1.6     Head, Mantle, and Feed Plate Description
The head, mantle, bowl, and liner make up the major components of the crushing 
chamber.
A torch ring is mounted on the top surface of the mantle, and a locking nut holds 
both in place. The feed plate is mounted on top of the locking nut. The feed plate 
protects the locking nut from wear and helps distribute material around the crushing 
cavity.
A head ball is secured in the head with an interference fit and sits in the socket liner 
mounted on top of the main shaft.
The head contains two bushings: an upper and a lower head bushing. The flanged 
lower head bushing provides bearing support for the eccentric, and the upper head 
bushing provides bearing support for the top of the head during no-load (non-
crushing) operation.1- Eccentric 2- Eccentric bushing 3- Counterweight 4- Counterweight guard
5- Gear 6- Upper Thrust Bearing 7- Upper U-seal 8- Lower T-seal
9- Caulking 10- Alignment dowel
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
10Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
A groove in the head contains a molded polyurethane T-shaped seal. This T-seal runs 
parallel with a similar U-shaped seal mounted in the adjoining counterweight. 
Together, they form a labyrinth seal that protects the inside of the crusher from dust 
infiltration and prevents excessive oil leakage.
 Figure 1-7:       Head, Mantle, and Feed Plate Assembly
1.7     Bowl Assembly Description
The outside diameter of the bowl contains greased heavy-duty right-hand threads 
that mate with corresponding threads in the clamping and adjustment rings, and that 
allow the bowl position to be adjusted vertically. The bowl rotates counterclockwise 
to open the closed side setting of the crushing cavity, and then rotates clockwise to 
close it.
The adjustment cap is mounted to the top of the bowl and contacts a rubber seal on 
the dust shell (which is bolted to the adjustment ring). The seal, adjustment cap and 
dust shell protect the greased threads from dust contamination. When pressurized, 
clamping cylinders (spaced around the top of the adjustment ring) provide a locking 
mechanism for holding the bowl in position during crushing. The bowl assembly is 
turned by a hydraulic adjustment mechanism mounted on the adjustment ring.
The feed hopper is designed to direct the feed into the crushing cavity. The flat 
bottom of the hopper provides a shelf for the incoming feed to collect and form a 
dead bed that contributes to the hopper wear protection.
Wedges, wedge bolts, and an adapter secure the bowl liner to the bowl. They are 
designed to accommodate various liner configurations.1- Feed plate 2- Locking nut 3- Upper head bushing
4- Head 5- Upper T-seal 6- Head stub/ball
7- Lower head bushing 8- Mantle 9- Torch ring
11Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
 Figure 1-8:       Bowl, Bowl Liner, and Hopper Assemblies
1.8     Bowl Adjustment Mechanism Description
The adjustment mechanism rotates the bowl assembly into and out of the 
adjustment ring assembly for bowl assembly maintenance and adjustments to the 
crusher cavity setting.
The assembly consists of four hydraulic drive assemblies, the drive ring with four 
turning brackets, and six drive ring support brackets. These parts turn the bowl for 
into and out of the crusher. 
Before turning the bowl, the clamping circuit must be depressurized so it releases the 
bowl. After a brief delay to ensure the clamping circuit pressure is completely 
released, the hydraulic drive motor mounted on the adjustment ring turns pinions 
that are mounted on the drive assembly. The teeth of the pinions engage teeth in the 
drive ring. Turning brackets on top of the drive ring match with lugs welded to the 
outside of the adjustment cap. The drive turns the bowl to open or close the closed 
side setting of the crusher.
In crushers with automation or optional remote calibration, two proximity sensors 
are mounted to one of the pinions’ covers; they count the pinion teeth, and the count 
is used to monitor the setting changes and liner life.
1.8.1     Drive Ring Support System
As the drive ring rotates, three drive ring retainers hold it in the same plane as the 
adjustment mechanism pinion. The retainers have a top and a bottom replaceable 
urethane support pad.1- Bowl liner 2- Bowl 3- Hopper
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
12Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
1.9     Lubrication System Description
The lubrication system sends filtered oil to the crusher to cool and lubricate the 
bushings. There is one lubrication line that sends oil to the eccentric and head 
bushings, and a separate line that sends oil to the socket liner. Oil exiting the crusher 
gravity-flows in one common return line back to the package lubrication system 
reservoir. Refer to Figure 1-9 “Lubrication System (Air Cooled)”  for the many 
components that make up the lubrication system.
 Figure 1-9:       Lubrication System (Air Cooled)
There are two lubrication packages available. The selection of your lubrication 
package is based on the oil-cooling requirement. 
The skid-mounted lubrication systems consist of the following:
•  Reservoir with a oil level sensor, temperature sensor, and oil heaters
•  Submerged oil pump attached to a vertically-positioned electric drive motor, 
which is mounted to the top of the oil reservoir
•  Main system relief valve set at 125 psi (8.6 bars)
•  20 micron filter system with 50 psi (0.34 bars) internal bypass monitored by two 
separate filter differential pressure switches1- Oil reservoir 2- Clean out cover 3- Oil filter
4- Oil pump motor 5- Oil drain connection 6- Inspection cover
13Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
•  Various isolation valves
•  Temperature transducers in the oil return line and the reservoir supply line 
(optional)
•  Heat exchanger
Mounted on the lubrication skid for water cooled systems
Remotely mounted for radiator-type
The large portion of the oil flows through a vertical gallery in the center of the 
crusher main shaft, where it lubricates the head ball, socket liner, and (during no load 
operations) the upper head bushing. An intersecting cross gallery in the main shaft 
carries the majority of the oil flow to lubricate the eccentric bushing and the lower 
head bushing. This oil flow provides cooling (heat transfer) from the bearing surfaces 
within the crusher. Oil exiting the bearing surfaces gravity flows through the slots in 
the counterweight, lubricating the gear and pinion on its way to the gear well and 
main frame sump. The oil then flows back to the lubrication system reservoir.
The oil flowing to the countershaft box bearings drains from the countershaft box 
into the main frame oil sump. It combines there with the rest of the lubricating oil. 
The oil flow to the countershaft box is controlled by the size of the flexible supply line 
and fittings.
1.9.1     Oil Filtration
The package lubrication system (PLS) uses a full flow oil filter with integral pressure 
relief, a replaceable 25 micron filter with integral pressure relief, a replaceable 25 
micron filter element, and two pressure switches to indicate dirty and plugged filter 
element conditions. These signals are sent to and processed by the automated 
control system (ACS). 
Under the oil tank cover is a removable and cleanable strainer basket that is designed 
to catch large particle contamination as the drain oil falls back into the tank.
1.9.2     Lubrication System Breather
The oil reservoir, which is sealed from dust and moisture, has a breather on the top of 
the tank. The breather maintains the reservoir atmospheric pressure.
1.9.3     Air Seal Blower
An air seal blower is connected by hose to the countershaft box to provide positive 
pressure inside the crusher. This device is required to allow the lubrication oil to drain 
freely from the crusher. Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
14Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
 Figure 1-10:       Crusher Air Seal Blower
1.9.4     Low Oil Level Sensor
The low oil level sensor is mounted on the side of the reservoir. The sensor monitors 
the oil level, and provides a signal to the control system when the level becomes low.
1.9.5     Oil Pressure Sensor
An analog pressure sensor protects the crusher in case of lost oil pressure. The sensor 
is wired to the control system, and a warning and alarm occurs when the pressure 
drops below acceptable levels.
1.9.6     Oil Temperature System
1.9.6.1      Oil Heater
The oil heater is mounted in the reservoir to maintain the oil temperature in cold 
operating conditions. The ACS operates the oil heaters. Equipment required for the 
heater operation, such as a magnetic contactor and fuse protection, is not provided 
with the crusher. The equipment must meet local electrical code requirements.
1.9.6.2      Heat Exchanger
The heat exchanger maintains the crusher drain oil temperature at 38° to 54°C (100° 
to 130°F).  The two most common types of oil coolers are oil-to-air and oil-to-water.
There is a relief valve located in a bypass line around both cooler designs. This allows 
pressure relief due to plugged internal passages or cold, thick oil. The valve is factory 
set; do not adjust it.1- Countershaft box 2- Hose 3- Air seal blower
15Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
Air-to-Oil Heat Exchanger
The air-to-oil heat exchanger is a radiator-type cooler that uses a fan to transfer the 
heat of the oil to air. The heat exchanger is shipped already mounted to a skid, with a 
bypass relief valve in place.
 Figure 1-11:       Air-to-Oil Heat Exchanger
Oil-to-Water Heat Exchanger
The oil-to-water heat exchanger is a tube and shell design that transfers the heat of 
the oil (circulated through the shell) into the water (circulated through the tubes).
The required flow of water is dependent on the oil temperature. A non-electrical 
temperature sensor mounted in a thermowell on the side of the lubrication tank 
works in conjunction with a water control valve on the cooler’s oil outlet port to 
automatically control the water flow as needed.
1.9.7     Temperature Sensors
There are two temperature transducers mounted on the oil reservoir. The 
transducers are wired to the automated control system, and monitor the oil 
temperature from two locations on the lubrication system.  Refer to the installation, 1- Air flow 2- Air-to-oil cooler 3- Fan motor
4- Pressure relief valve 5- Supply oil temperature transducer

16Chapter 1: Equipment Overview
operation, and maintenance manual fo r the transducer location on the heat 
exchanger.
1.9.7.1      Reservoir Oil Temperature
A temperature probe in the reservoir is connected to a temperature sensor in the 
electrical control panel. The control system uses the sensor’s analog signal to control 
the oil heater and to manage the oil pump start permissive.
1.9.7.2      Return Oil Temperature
A temperature sensor probe in the return line connection on the side of the reservoir 
is connected to the return temperature transducer. The control system uses the signal 
to activate the high oil temperature warning and alarm.
If the crusher oil is cooled by an air-to-oil heat exchanger, an optional additional 
return line temperature sensor controls the fan motor.
1.9.7.3      Supply Oil Temperature
If the crusher oil is cooled by an air-to-oil heat exchanger, an additional supply oil 
temperature sensor is mounted in the piping.
If the crusher oil is cooled by an oil-to-water heat exchanger, the supply oil 
temperature sensor is adjacent to the 2-inch NPT connection on the package 
lubrication system, wired to the transducer in the electrical box. The sensor provides 
an analog signal to the control system.17Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
