FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
2.1     Maintenance Overview
This chapter provides detailed information on maintaining the equipment and its 
systems safely and efficiently. Regular care and maintenance must be performed as 
outlined in this chapter.
For maintenance instructions specific to an accessory piece of equipment (item 
which is furnished by FLSmidth but is fabricated by a third party) refer to the original 
equipment manufacturer documentation. 
Do not install, operate, maintain, or repair this equipment unless you have read 
and understand the instructions and warnings in Chapter 1: Safety. Failure to follow 
these safety precautions could result in personal injury, death, or property damage.
2.1.1     Welding and Weld Repair of Major Castings
The main frame, bowl, head, and adjustment ring are critical components in the 
function of the crusher. These specific parts are cast using high alloy steel that has 
special welding requirements. Before doing any welding on these specific parts, a 
certified welder must submit a weld procedure specification (WPS) to FLSmidth 
engineering for review. The failure to provide a WPS for review voids the crusher 
warranty.
2.1.2     Introduction
Maintenance involving the disassembly of the crusher requires a thorough 
understanding of the components that make up the Crusher, and how they interact 
during the operation of the crusher. Refer to Chapter 1: “Equipment Overview” on 
page 1.
Exercise great care while performing maintenance to avoid damaging the crusher 
components.
Take the following precautions when working on the crusher:
•  Handle parts with care if they have bearings, or machined or journal surfaces. 
These parts are either designed to close tolerances or are critical surfaces.
Do not allow these parts to contact hard surfaces. Support the parts on 
wooden blocking or rubber mats.
Do not install any part that has a bearing or journal surface without first coat -
ing it with oil.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
22Chapter 2: Maintenance
•  Handle and install bronze bushings with great care.
Bronze is soft; ramming or pounding a bushing during installation may cause 
distortion or other damage.
•  Coat mating parts that have either a press or sliding fit with light oil to prevent 
rusting in place.
•  Thoroughly clean and oil any machined parts prior to installation.
2.1.3     Thermal Process for Removal and Installation
Thermal procedures are required for the removal and subsequent installation of 
some components.
•  The components can be damaged by improper heating techniques. Whenever 
possible, heat the components in an oil bath, temperature-controlled oven, or 
induction heater.
•  Establishing a uniform, soaking heat of the minimum temperature necessary. 
•  Do not use cutting torches as a heating tool. Concentrated heat from a cutting 
torch will result in hot spots that may cause dimensional distortions or cause 
residual stress concentrations and can adversely surface harden parts. Excessive 
localized heating can cause stress cracks.
•  Oxygen acetylene or oxygen propane torches are not recommended; only use 
these torches if it is the only method available, and only with great care. Use a 
burner tip that provides a diffused flame if the torch is used.
•  If flame heating of gearing must be used, avoid direct flame contact with the 
hardened surfaces. Instead, warm the bore and internal faces, and allow the 
heat to slowly soak to the outside.
•  Do not exceed the provided target temperature. Overheating can damage parts 
by affecting the metallurgy and causing residual stress concentrations.
•  Apply heat rapidly and evenly when heating parts for removal, and then remove 
the part as quickly as possible to minimize heat transfer to the mating part.
•  Do not quench parts in liquid to cool them. If fast cooling is required, limit the 
cooling speed to that which can be attained with a fan or compressed air stream.
2.2     Start-Up After Major Maintenance Event
After replacing a bearing or the eccentric bushing, the power draw must be re-
measured.
1. Allow the crusher to run until the lubrication tank oil reaches a consistent tem -
perature, but for no longer than two hours.
2. Record the crusher drive motor power draw.
Note: The power draw peaks must never go above 110%.
2.3     Lower Thrust Bearing Replacement
The lower thrust bearing must be replaced due to damage or wear.23Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
2.3.1     Lower Thrust Bearing Removal
1. Remove the bo wl, head, socket, and eccentric assemblies in order to access the 
lower thrust bearing. Refer to the installation, operation, and maintenance 
(IOM) manual.
2. Remove the hex head capscrews and spring washers that retain the thrust bear -
ing to the frame hub. Refer to Figure 2-1: “Lower Thrust Bearing and Shims” on 
page 24.
3. Use two M12  ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) to lift the thrust 
bearing out of the crusher.
2.3.2     Lower Thrust Bearing Installation
The maintenance log is required for this procedure. Refer to A.1 “Lower Thrust 
Bearing Installation Log” on page 60. 
1. Remove any burrs or upset edges on the new thrust bearing and shims that will 
not allow flat contact on the top surface of the main frame hub.
2. Determine the correct number and size of shims to be placed between the main 
frame and thrust bearing. Refer to the backlash inspection instructions in the 
installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual .
3. If additional shims are required, place them on top of the existing shim stack.
4. Place the thrust bearing on the shim  stack, making sure the bearing and shims 
are seated and aligned properly.
5. Insert a new hex head capscrews and new spring washers through the thrust 
bearing and shims, and screw them into the tapped holes in the main frame. 
6. Using a crossing pattern, tighten all the capscrews to 1043 N-m (769 ft-lbs) .
 Figure 2-1:       Lower Thrust Bearing and Shims1- Hex head capscrew 2- Lower thrust bearing 3- Shims
4- Main frame 5- Spring washer 6- Main shaft
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
24Chapter 2: Maintenance
7. When a new bearing is installed, the power draw must be re-measured.
a.  Allow the crusher to run for eight hours.
b.  Record the closed side setting.
c.  Record the crusher drive motor power draw in the Maintenance Log in A.1 
“Lower Thrust Bearing Installation Log” on page 60.
Note: The power draw peaks must never go above 110%.
2.4     Adjustment Ring Seating Surface Reconditioning
We promise instructions on how to recondition the adjustment ring seating surface.
2.5     Tramp Release Cylinder Replacement
Replace or rebuild the tramp release cylinder as soon as a leak develops. A leaking 
cylinder allows excessive adjustment ring movement.
Tramp release cylinder replacement kits are referenced on the Tramp Release 
Cylinder Assembly in the installation, operation, and maintenance manual.
2.5.1     Tramp Release Cylinder Removal
1. Install a 20 mm (78.7 in) ring bolt (supplied in the special tools package) in the 
threaded hole at the top of the tramp release cylinder piston rod.
2. Attach a clevis and a suitable cable sling to the cylinder. The sling must be:
Strong enough to support the cylinder
Small enough to pass through the 80 mm (3.1 in) hex nut on the piston rod
Long enough to lower the cylinder to the below deck
3. Detach the support shackle and cable from the main frame flange.
4. Verify that the tramp release system pressure is zero.
5. Open the tramp release circuit dump valve to ensure there is no residual pres -
sure. Leave the dump valve open throughout the removal of the cylinder.
Do not disconnect any hoses from the system without first verifying that there 
is no pressure in the system.
A hose disconnection under high pressure is dangerous, and can cause serious 
harm from the escaping high velocity oil and the possibility of being hit by a 
whipping hose.
6. Remove all the hoses from the tramp release cylinder.
25Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
a.  Displaced oil in the system will fall from the hose. Be prepared to catch the oil 
in a container.
7. Pull the piston rod upward with an overhead lifting device, and loosen the 80 
mm (3.1 in) hex nut.
8. Lower the tramp release cylinder to the bottom crusher flange.
The upper cone will remain in the main frame cup.
The lower cone will remain on the cylinder head.
9. While the cylinder is still partially supported by the overhead lifting device, walk 
or slide the tramp release cylinder off of the main frame flange and onto the 
surrounding foundation or access deck.
10. Carefully balance the tramp release cylinder, and disconnect the clevis and sling.
11. Lift the cylinder away with a nylon sling and a choker hitch.
Note: It may be necessary to remove the upper decking to remove the cylinder.
2.5.2     Tramp Release Cylinder Installation
1. Attach a sling around the cylinder so that it passes between the tramp release 
cylinder and the integral bypass tube. This will prevent the tube from becoming 
damaged when it is lifted. The sling must be situated so that when the cylinder is 
later lifted, it hangs as vertically as possible with the clevis facing down.
2. Remove any burrs from the clevis pin, and coat it with moly grade anti-seize 
grease.
3. Carefully lift the cylinder, and guide the top cylinder rod up through the adjust -
ment ring to prevent damaging the rod threads.
4. Slide the cylinder clevis onto the main frame rib.
5. Install a cotter pin in each end of the clevis pin.
6. Clean the threaded portion of the rod, and the hex nut threads with an oil-free 
solvent such as acetone or alcohol, and coat the threads with Loctite 277.
7. Reinstall the spherical washer on the rod, and coat the radius with moly grade 
anti-seize grease.
8. Install the hex nut onto the rod until the proper distance between the bottom of 
the adjustment ring and the top of the cylinder hub is achieved.
9. Connect the hoses to the cylinder.
10. Bleed the tramp release system of any trapped air. Refer to the installation, 
operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual. 
11. Pressurize the tramp release system. Refer to the installation, operation, and 
maintenance (IOM) manual.
12. Verify that the distance between the bottom of the adjustment ring and the 
tramp release cylinder matches the specifications on drawing “RXL903-5001—Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
26Chapter 2: Maintenance
Tramp Release Cylinder Assembly” on page 470, and make any necessary adjust -
ments.
2.6     Clamping Ring Replacement
2.6.1     Clamping Ring Removal
1. Depressurize all the clamping cylinders; refer to the installation, operation, and 
maintenance manual. Ensure the clamp circuit pressure indicated on the trans -
ducer is zero.
2. Remove the bowl assembly. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
3. Unbolt the dust shell, and remove it from the top of the adjustment ring.
4. Remove the eight 48 mm hex bolts and sleeves. Refer to Figure 2-4.
 Figure 2-2:       Clamping Ring Spacers and Capscrews
5. Disconnect the clamping circuit hose fitting. Refer to Figure 2-3 "Clamping Cir -
cuit Hose Connection" on page 27.1- Clamping ring 2- Capscrew 3- Flat washer
4- Tube spacer 5- Adjustment ring
27Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-3:       Clamping Circuit Hose Connection
6. Install two M36  ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) in the clamping 
ring, and attach lifting cables.  Refer to Figure 2-4.
7. Remove the clamping ring.
 Figure 2-4:       Removing the Clamping Ring
2.6.2     Clamping Ring Installation
1. Install two M36  ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) on the clamp -
ing ring, and attach lifting cables.
2. Position the clamping ring as shown in Figure 2-5.1- Hose connection

3. Install eight 48 mm bolts and spacers (not supplied with the crusher) as shown in 
Figure 2-4.
4. Connect the hydraulic supply hose to the clamping cylinder hose loop. Refer to 
Figure 2-3 "Clamping Circuit Hose Connection" on page 27.
Note: The hydraulic supply hose is the vertical hose coming from the adjustment 
ring.
5. Inspect all the clamp cylinder hose connections to verify that they are tight.
6. Apply a liberal coating of molybdenum disulfide grease to the adjustment and 
clamping ring threads.
2.7     Main Frame Pin Replacement
Ring bounce, where the adjustment ring lifts or bounces quickly on and off the main 
frame seat liners, causes wear to the main frame pins and pin bushings which are 
mounted in the main frame flange. This wear can be seen by looking at the underside 
of the adjustment ring and at the top and bottom of the pin bushings.
While under load, the head turns counterclockwise. The bowl and adjustment ring 
are prevented from also turning counterclockwise, but the constant force causes the 
pins and pin bushings to wear more on one side.
2.7.1     Pin Removal
1. Remove the bowl assembly from the crusher. Refer to the installation, operation, 
and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2. Remove the adjustment ring from the crusher. Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
3. Remove the hex bolt and washers from the bottom side of the main frame pins. 
Refer to Figure 2-6.
4. Heat the main frame pin boss, while driving the pin out the top of the main 
frame. 1- Positioning holes 2- Starting thread on adjustment ring
29Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Note: If needed to increase the ease of pin removal, lance the pin prior to heat -
ing the main frame.
 Figure 2-6:       Main Frame Pin Replacement
2.7.2     Pin Installation
1. Cool the pins and heat the main frame to create a temperature difference of 
120°C (216°F) .
2. Insert the pins into the main frame.
3. Reinstall the hex bolt and fender washer.
4. Replace the pin bushings if needed. Refer to 2.8 “Main Frame Pin Bushing 
Replacement” on page 30.
5. Install the adjustment ring back into the frame. Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2.8     Main Frame Pin Bushing Replacement
Pack the replacement bushings in dry ice for at least two hours before replacing the 
existing bushings.
2.8.1     Pin Bushing Removal
1. Remove the bowl assembly from the crusher. Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2. Remove the adjustment ring from the crusher. Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
3. Remove the hex bolts and pin cover  from the bushings that are being replaced.
4. Heat the adjustment ring around the pin bushing, and drive the bushing out of 
the top of the adjustment ring.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
30Chapter 2: Maintenance
2.8.2     Pin Bushing Installation
1. Heat the adjustment ring boss for 10 to 15 minutes until the temperature differ -
ence between the adjustment ring boss and the pin bushing is at least 102°C 
(184°F).
Note: The new bushing must have been packed in dry ice for at least two hours 
before installation.
2. Drop the cooled pin bushing quickly into the adjustment ring bore, making sure 
that the holes in the pin bushing line up with the tapped holes in the adjustment 
ring.
Note: The position of the flat on the bushing is not important.
3. Reinstall the caps and hardware.
4. Inspect the main frame pins to determine if any must be replaced. Replace any 
needed pins. Refer to 2.7 “Main Frame Pin Replacement” on page 29.
5. Install the adjustment ring onto the frame. Refer to the installation, operation, 
and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2.9     Countershaft Box Assembly Replacement
Inspect the countershaft box assembly condition any time it is removed from the 
crusher.
2.9.1     Countershaft Box Assembly Removal
When removing the countershaft box assembly from the crusher, do not remove 
the sheave bushing from the countershaft. This will ensure that the countershaft 
and pinion do not slide out of the box while handling the assembly.
1. Remove the outer box bushing temperature sensor by loosening the mounting 
adapter nut and sliding the probe out of the box. Use caution to avoid damaging 
the probe or cable.  Refer to Figure 2-7.
31Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-7:       Countershaft Box Assembly
2. Remove all the oil piping attached to the countershaft box, and plug the open -
ings.
3. Remove all of the capscrews that secure the countershaft box to the main 
frame.
4. Thread three jackscrews (supplied in the special tools package) into the three 
equally spaced tapped holes in the countershaft box flange until they bottom 
out. Refer to Figure 2-8.
 Figure 2-8:       Countershaft Box Removal1- Pinion 2- Countershaft 3- Oil flinger
4- Cover 5- Outer countershaft bushing 6- Inner countershaft bushing
7- Countershaft box 8- Piston ring seal 9- Temperature probe location
1- Main frame 2- Jackscrews 3- Countershaft
4- Cover 5- Countershaft box
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
32Chapter 2: Maintenance
5. Attach a lifting sling around the sheave end of the countershaft box, and apply 
just enough tension to take the slack out of the sling. Refer to Figure 2-9.
Note: The sling will prevent the countershaft box from falling when it is removed 
from the main frame bore.
 Figure 2-9:       Slings Around Countershaft Assembly
6. Tighten the countershaft box jackscrews in small increments in a crisscross pat -
tern. This will prevent the box from binding to the frame bore.
7. Continue jacking the countershaft box until it is free of the frame.
8. Place a long piece of pipe over the drive end of the countershaft to offset the 
heavier pinion end.
9. Remove the assembly. Refer to Figure 2-9 "Slings Around Countershaft Assem -
bly" on page 32.
2.9.2     Countershaft Box Assembly Installation
The countershaft box is factory assembled with end float, or clearance, to allow for 
the extension and retraction of the countershaft in the box caused by heating and 
cooling cycles. When installing a repaired or replacement countershaft box assembly, 
inspect the end float.
1. Pull on the pinion until the flinger contacts the outer countershaft bushing.
2. Measure the float end gap between the pinion and the inner countershaft bush -
ing flange with a feeler gauge.
Note: The gap must be 0.8 to 1.6 mm (0.031 to 0.063 in).
3. If the float end gap is incorrect:
a.  Remove the crusher sheave. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
b.  Remove the sheave bushing. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.1- Lifting sling 2- Countershaft 3- Countershaft box centering lug 4- Installation guide and rest (main frame
33Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
c.  If there is a safety set collar mounted on the countershaft, loosen and slide it 
off.
d.  Remove the cover from the countershaft box.
e.  If the end float gap is too small, heat the flinger to 106°C (190°F)  above ambi -
ent temperature, and tap the countershaft on the sheave end until the cor -
rect end float measurement is attained.
f.  If the end float gap is too large, insert a feeler gauge between the pinion and 
the inner bushing flange. Clamp the pinion tightly against the bushing, and 
heat the flinger to 106°C (109°F)  above ambient temperature . Refer to 
Figure 2-10 . Push the flinger against the outer bushing flange, and allow the 
flinger to cool before removing the clamp and feeler gauge.
 Figure 2-10:       Holding the Countershaft
4. Insert the countershaft box assembly into the main frame using a sling.
a.  Place a long piece of pipe over the outer end of the countershaft to balance 
the assembly. Refer to Figure 2-9 "Slings Around Countershaft Assembly" on 
page 32.
b.  Lift the assembly, and insert it  into  the outer main frame bore while carefully 
positioning the box . Center the countershaft box lug on the guide plate in the 
bottom of the bore . 
5. Apply anti-seize to the jackscrews (supplied in the special tools package). The 
anti-seize protects the threads from damage caused by the pulling forces.
6. Insert the jackscrews equally spaced through the holes located in the outer 
countershaft box flange until they thread into the tapped holes in the main 
frame.
7. In small increments, tighten the jackscrews in a crisscross pattern to prevent the 
interface fit between the outer main frame bore and the countershaft box from 
binding. Continue tightening the jackscrews until they bottom out in the main 
frame tapped holes.1- C-clamp 2- Countershaft box bushing 3- Pinion
4- No clearance 5- Shim
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
34Chapter 2: Maintenance
8. Remove the bottomed-out jackscrews, and place washers or spacers on them. 
Refer to Step 2 in Figure 2-11 .
 Figure 2-11:       Sliding Countershaft Box Into Main Frame
9. Reinsert the jackscrews, and again tighten them in small increments until they 
bottom out in the main frame.
10. Remove the jackscrews again.
11. Install the original shims.
12. Place lock washers on the capscrews that hold the countershaft box assembly in 
the main frame. 
13. Apply anti-seize to the capscrews.
14. Press the countershaft box assembly into the main frame by alternately tighten -
ing the capscrews until the countershaft box flange is tight against the frame. 
Refer to Step 3 in Figure 2-11 .
15. Install the crusher sheave onto the countershaft. Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
16. Install the drive . Refer to the installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) 
manual.1- Main frame 2- Washer spacers 3- Jackscrew 4- Countershaft box
5- Lockwasher 6- Regular countershaft box hex head capscrews 7- No clearance 8- Shims

FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
2.10     Countershaft Replacemen t
2.10.1     Countershaft Removal
1. Remove the countershaft box assembly from the crusher. Refer to 2.9.1 
“Countershaft Box Assembly Removal” on page 31.
2. Remove the sheave and bushing from the countershaft. Refer to the installation, 
operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual .
3. Remove the countershaft box cover.
4. Heat the oil flinger to 104°C (219°F)  above ambient temperature.
Note: There is an interface fit between the oil flinger and the countershaft.
5. Position a pry bar between the flinger and the countershaft box, and apply pres -
sure. 
6. When the flinger starts to move, apply force to both sides of the flinger, and 
slide it off the countershaft. 
7. Slide the countershaft and pinion out of the countershaft box.
8. Measure the shaft run out. 
a.  If the run out exceeds 0.102 mm (0.004 in), the shaft must be replaced. Oth -
erwise, it may continue to be used.
9. Inspect the shaft for any twisting. Operating the crusher with a bent or twisted 
countershaft causes excessive vibration and may lead to premature box bushing 
failure.
2.10.2     Countershaft Installation
1. Use an emery cloth to remove any burrs and buff any scratches found on the 
countershaft, the inside of the countershaft box and the surfaces of the counter -
shaft box bushings.
2. Coat the countershaft bushings with lubrication oil and carefully slide the 
countershaft into the countershaft box until the pinion contacts the counter -
shaft bushing flange.
3. Place a 0.51 to 0.64 mm (0.002 to 0.025 in)  thick shim between the pinion and 
countershaft box bushing flange to establish the required end float.
4. Clamp the pinion to the countershaft box. Refer to Figure 2-10 "Holding the 
Countershaft" on page 33.
5. Heat the oil flinger to 104°C  (219°F)above ambient temperature
Note: There is an interference fit between the oil flinger and countershaft.
6. Slide the flinger onto the countershaft until it is against the countershaft bush -
ing flange. There is a piston ring seal mounted in a groove in the oil flinger that 
provides an oil seal with the cover. Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
36Chapter 2: Maintenance
7. Verify that the ring is free to turn in the flinger groove. 
8. Apply a light coat of grease.
9. Inspect the inner bore of the cover, verifying that it is smooth and has no 
grooves worn into it by the piston ring. 
a.  If a groove is starting to show, machine the bore to remove the groove. A ring 
that is allowed to wear too deeply into the cover will make removing the 
cover difficult.
10. Place a new gasket on the cover.
11. Slide the cover onto the oil flinger and bolt it to the countershaft box.
12. Install the bushing and sheave onto the countershaft. Refer to the installation, 
operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
13. Remove the clamp holding the pinion to the countershaft box and remove the 
spacer.
14. Install the countershaft box assembly. Refer to 2.9.2 “Countershaft Box Assembly 
Installation” on page 33.
2.11     Countershaft Bushing Replacement
If either of the two countershaft box bushings are loose in the countershaft box as a 
result of wear, remove the bushing(s) and inspect the box bore(s) to verify that they 
are within factory specifications. Then the loose bushing(s) may be replaced. 
2.11.1     Countershaft Bushing Removal
Operating the crusher with inadequate lubrication, in an overloaded condition, or 
with over-tensioned V-belts may cause the bushings to overheat, fail, and seize in the 
countershaft box. This makes the bushings more difficult to remove.
1. Remove the countershaft box assembly from the crusher. Refer to 2.9.1 
“Countershaft Box Assembly Removal” on page 31.
2. Remove the countershaft from the countershaft box assembly. Refer to 2.10.1 
“Countershaft Removal” on page 35.
3. Fabricate a steel bushing removal plate (not supplied with the crusher). Refer to 
Figure 2-12 .
The plate must be 25 mm (1 in thick)
The plate width must be narrower than the inside of the bushing
The plate height must be taller than the inside of the bushing
Weld a 25 mm (1 in) hex nut to the center of the plate37Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-12:       Bushing Plate Removal
4. Slide the narrow part of the steel bushing removal plate into the bushing until it 
is positioned behind the bushing.
5. Turn the plate 90 degrees until it contacts the bushing.
6. Hold the plate in place and thread a 25 mm (1 in) diameter rod that is threaded 
on both ends into the nut on the removal plate. 
Note: The rod must be a few inches longer than the bushing.1- Center of bushing 2- Countershaft bushing 3- Steel bushing removal plate 4- Width
5- Height 6- Plate thickness 7- Hex nut
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
38Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-13:       Removing the Countershaft Bushing by Ramming
7. Drill a 30 mm (1.12 in) hole in the center of a 25 x 75 x 305 mm (1 x 3 x 12 in) 
steel bar. 
8. Place the bar onto the threaded rod and hold it in place with a 25 mm (1 in) hex 
nut. Refer to Figure 2-13
9. Slide a timber or a piece of pipe into the opposite end of the box, and ram it 
against the removal plate to force the bushing out of the box bore. 
10. If ramming the plate against the bushing is not enough to remove it:
a.  Thread a longer rod than the one previously used into the removal plate nut. 
b.  Mount the steel bar onto the new rod, and place wood blocking between the 
steel bar and the countershaft box flange.
c.  Tighten the 25 mm (1 in) hex nut on the rod, using it as a jackscrew, until the 
bushing is pulled tightly against the steel bar. 
d.  Place additional blocking under the bar, and tighten the hex nut until the 
bushing is again drawn to the bar. 
e.  Repeat these above steps until the bushing is pulled free of the countershaft 
box bore.1- Countershaft box 2- Bushing removal plate 3- Dowel 4- Flat bar
5- Countershaft bushing 6- Threaded rod 7- Timber
39Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-14:       Countershaft Bushing Removal by Jacking
2.11.2     Countershaft Bushing Installation
1. Measure the bushing and countershaft box inside and outside diameters. 
Countershaft bushings are manufactured to provide a 0.05 mm  fit in the box 
bore. 
a.  If the measurements indicate that the interference fit will be too tight, 
machine the countershaft box bore to obtain the proper fit. 
Note: If the interference fit is too tight, the bushing bore will collapse when 
the bushing is installed. This will reduce the running clearance between the 
bushing bore and the countershaft, causing premature bushing failure and 
possibly causing the bushing to seize to the countershaft. 
2. Remove the two dowels from the countershaft box flange face.
3. Make two rods that are the same diameter as the removed dowels and 25 mm 
(1 in) longer than the bushing. Insert the rods in the dowel holes.1- Flat bar 2- Blocking 3- Countershaft bushing
4- Countershaft box 5- Bushing removal plate 6- Threaded rod
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
40Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-15:       Countershaft Bushing
4. Mount the inner and outer bushing with the oil groove positioned correctly.
Note: The inner and outer countershaft bushings are identical. The difference 
between them is the position of their longitudinal oil groove in the countershaft 
box bore.
a.  For the inner bushing (pinion end), the oil groove must be at the top of the of 
the countershaft box bore, or at the 12:00 position.1- Steel guide rods 2- Countershaft bushings 3- Countershaft box
41Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-16:       Inner Countershaft Bushing Oil Groove Location
b.  Position the outer bushing (sheave end) with the oil groove at the bottom of 
the countershaft box bore at the 6:00 position .
 Figure 2-17:       Outer Countershaft Bushing Oil Groove Position
5. Chill the new bushing until it is 38°C (68°F)  cooler than the box.
6. Quickly slide the bushing into the countershaft box bore using the installed rods 
as guides.1- Oil groove 12:00 position 2- Inner countershaft bushing 3- Countershaft box
1- Counterhsaft box 2- Outer countershaft bushing 3- Oil groove 6:00 position
12
3Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
42Chapter 2: Maintenance
a.  If the bushing is not installed quickly enough and it gets stuck in the counter -
shaft box bore, place a block of wood across the face of the bushing to pro -
tect it, and use two clamps to pull the bushing the rest of the way in. Evenly 
tighten the clamps to ensure the bushing does not cock in the countershaft 
box bore.
7. Remove the guide rods, and replace them with the dowel pins. 
8. Set the end float, and complete the assembly of the countershaft box. Refer to 
2.10.2 “Countershaft Installation” on page 35.
9. Re-install the countershaft box assembly in the crusher. Refer to 2.9.2 “Counter -
shaft Box Assembly Installation” on page 33.
2.12     Pinion Replacement
Inspect the pinion for wear and damage any time the countershaft assembly is 
removed from the crusher. Excessive pinion wear typically includes pitting and galling 
of the teeth surfaces. Damage may include broken teeth. Replace excessively worn or 
damaged pinions.
Pinions with broken teeth cause excessive vibration, which leads to the damage of 
other internal crusher components. To maximize the benefits of installing a new 
pinion, replace the eccentric gear at the same time; refer to the installation, 
operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual. The use of a new pinion with an existing 
gear requires inspecting the contact pattern and backlash, and adjusting the settings 
if necessary. Refer to the installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2.12.1     Pinion Removal
1. Remove the countershaft box assembly from the crusher. Refer to 2.9.1 
“Countershaft Box Assembly Removal” on page 31.
2. Remove the countershaft and pinion from the countershaft box. Refer to 2.10.1 
“Countershaft Removal” on page 35.
3. Heat the pinion evenly with a torch until it is 138°C (280°F)  warmer than the 
countershaft.
4. Continue to apply heat while bumping the pinion. When the pinion starts to 
move, slide it off the countershaft.43Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-18:       Pinion and Countershaft Detail 
2.12.2     Pinion Installation
1. Heat the new pinion evenly with a torch until it is 138°C (280°F)  warmer than 
the countershaft.
2. Quickly slide the pinion onto the end of the countershaft so the end of the shaft 
is sticking out of the pinion 5 mm (0.2 in).
2.13     Addressing Countershaft Box Drive End Oil Leakage
1. Inspect the piston ring seal in the oil flinger groove for wear and damage. 
Replace the piston ring seal if wear or damage are detected:
a.  Remove the crusher sheave. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
b.  Remove the countershaft box cover. Refer to 2.10.1 “Countershaft Removal” 
on page 35.
c.  Remove the sheave bushing. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual .
d.  Remove the flinger cover. Refer to 2.10.1 “Countershaft Removal” on 
page 35.1- Pinion 2- Countershaft 3- Amount the shaft must stick out of the pinion
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
44Chapter 2: Maintenance
e.  Remove the worn or damaged piston ring seal from the groove in the oil 
flinger.
f.  Clean the groove.
g.  Install a new piston ring seal.
h.  Install the sheave bushing. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual .
i.  Install the flinger cover. Refer to 2.10.2 “Countershaft Installation” on page 35.
j.  Mount the crusher sheave. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
2. Inspect the long cored passage in the lower chapter of the countershaft box for 
sludge buildup.
Note: Buildup limits oil flow to the flinger area and causes oil to leak out from 
between the countershaft and flinger cover.
3. Inspect the pitch of the crusher oil drain line. The drain line must have a mini -
mum pitch of 25 mm (1 in) vertical rise for every 305 mm (12 in) of horizontal 
run. 
Note: If the pitch is too shallow, the oil does not flow properly out of the crusher, 
and leaks out from between the countershaft box area. This problem is 
increased with cold oil conditions.
4. Inspect the inside of the drain line for dirt, sludge buildup, or a collapsed hose. 
Note: Any restriction to proper oil flow will cause oil leakage.
2.14     Addressing Countershaft Box Pinion End Oil 
Leakage
2.15     Gear Maintenance
Inspect the bevel gear that is mounted on the underside of the eccentric whenever 
the eccentric assembly is removed from the crusher and when there is a concern 
regarding excessively worn or broken gear teeth. Excessive gear wear is indicated by a 
step worn in the profile of the teeth, or pitting and galling of the profile.
During every liner change, verify the torque on all capscrews connecting the gear to 
the eccentric.
2.15.1     Gear Removal
1. Remove the counterweight. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
2. Remove the capscrews running through the eccentric flange into tapped holes in 
the gear. 45Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Note: These capscrews were installed with Loctite, requiring heat to be 
removed.
3. Install two M36  ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) into the eccen -
tric assembly lifting ring.
Note: There is a slight interference fit between the eccentric flange and a 
counter bore in the top of the gear. 
4. Attach the proper equipment to the eccentric ring bolts, and lift the eccentric 38 
mm (1.5 in) above the wood blocks.
5. Evenly heat the gear all around with a torch until the gear expands enough to 
fall off the eccentric onto the wood blocking.
a.  If the upper thrust bearing is to be removed, place the eccentric on its side on 
wood blocks to protect the machined surfaces and then refer to 2.16.2 
“Upper Thrust Bearing Removal” on page 48.
b.  If the upper thrust bearing is not to be removed, place the eccentric on wood 
blocks to protect the machined surface of the upper thrust bearing.
2.15.2     Gear Installation
1. If the upper thrust bearing was removed:
a.  Turn the eccentric upside down, and place it on wood blocks
b.  Install the bearing, referring to 2.16.3 “Upper Thrust Bearing Installation” on 
page 48.
c.  Turn the eccentric right side up, and place it on wood blocks to protect the 
machined surface of the thrust bearing.
2. Place the gear on wood blocks with the teeth facing down. Clean all the tapped 
holes in the gear with an oil-free solvent such as alcohol or acetone. 
Note: Loctite will be applied to these holes later.
3. With the eccentric lifting ring and lifting ring bolts attached to the top of the 
eccentric, lift the eccentric until it is safely suspended above the gear by approx -
imately 305 mm (12 in). Center the eccentric over the gear counter bore.
4. Measure the eccentric flange diameter and the gear counter bore for use later.
5. Using a torch, evenly heat the gear all around the counter bore area until it is 
26°C (47°F)  warmer than the eccentric.Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
46Chapter 2: Maintenance
It is critical that the gear be evenly heated and that the supply of heat is not 
concentrated in one spot or area. Heating in one spot or area could destroy the 
heat treatment of the gear. A chemical marking device designed to melt at a 
specified temperature can be used to make sure over heating does not occur.
An infrared pyrometer or digital contact thermometer may also be used.
6. Measure the gear counter bore while it is being heated. 
7. Once the counter bore has expanded to a diameter slightly larger than the 
eccentric flange, quickly lower the eccentric into the counter bore in the gear. 
Align the eccentric mounting holes with the tapped holes in the gear.
 Figure 2-19:       Gear Mounting Holes
8. Clean the threads on the capscrews which connect the eccentric to the gear with 
an oil-free solvent such as acetone or alcohol. 
Note: If the bolts required heating to remove, they must be replaced. Otherwise, 
they may be reused.
9. Apply Loctite 27 1 to the capscrew threads, and install them with hardened 
washers in the tapped holes in the gear.
10. Torque the capscrews using a crisscross pattern to 2733 n-m (2016 ft-lbs) .1- Gear mounting holes 2- Counterweight locating dowel 3- Eccentric flange
47Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Using an impact gun may break the Loctite, allowing the bolts to loosen and 
back out.
2.16     Upper Thrust Bearing Maintenance
2.16.1     Upper Thrust Bearing Inspection
1. Inspect the bronze upper thrust bearing for wear any time the eccentric assem -
bly is removed from the crusher. Replace the bearing when the oil groove depth 
becomes 14.2 mm (0.56 in)  or more shallow due to wear. 
Note: The original oil grooves are 16 mm (0.63 in)  deep.
2. Add shims under the steel lower thrust bearing as needed to reestablish the 
proper backlash setting after upper thrust bearing wear causes the backlash 
measurement to change.
3. Replace the upper and lower thrust bearing before contact occurs with the cap -
screws that secure the bearings.
 Figure 2-20:       Upper Thrust Bearing Wear1- Minimum groove depth 2- Original groove depth 3- Upper thrust bearing
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
48Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-21:       Upper Thrust Bearing
2.16.2     Upper Thrust Bearing Removal
1. Turn the eccentric assembly upside down on wood blocking to access the upper 
thrust bearing.
2. Remove the socket head capscrews and lock washers that bolt the upper thrust 
bearing to the eccentric.
3. Use two M12 ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) to lift and remove 
the upper thrust bearing from the eccentric.
2.16.3     Upper Thrust Bearing Installation
1. Inspect the new thrust bearing for burrs or upset edges. Verify it will be able to 
sit flat on the eccentric.
2. Using the same ring bolts used to remove the old bearing, lift and install the new 
bearing onto the bottom of the eccentric, verifying that the bearing mounting 
holes align with the eccentric tapped holes.
3. Use a feeler gauge between the bearing and eccentric to verify that the bearing 
is seated flat against the eccentric.
4. Tighten the six socket head capscrews that fasten the bearing to the eccentric 
using a crisscross pattern to 373 N-m (275 ft-lbs).
5. Turn the eccentric right side up and place it on wood blocks to protect the 
machined surface of the thrust bearing.1- Upper thrust bearing 2- Socket head capscrews 3- Spring washer
4- Eccentric bushing 5- Eccentric 6- Gear
49Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
2.17     Eccentric Bushing Maintenance
Inspect the eccentric bushing for inside diameter wear and for looseness in the 
eccentric bore whenever the eccentric assembly is removed from the crusher.
Both the top inside diameter of the eccentric and the top outside diameter of the 
bushing have four pockets. During manufacturing, the pockets were aligned and filled 
with an epoxy-locking compound to prevent the bushing from turning in the 
eccentric.
If the bushing has turned in the eccentric bore, it must be removed and inspected. 
Measure the inside and outside diameters in three places (top, middle, and bottom) 
to verify that the inside diameter has not changed and the bushing diameter has not 
pulled in.
Contact FLSmidth with the measurements to determine whether the bushing is 
usable or it must be replaced.
2.17.1     Eccentric Bushing Removal from the Eccentric 
Assembly
1. Remove the counterweight. Refer to the installation, operation, and mainte -
nance (IOM) manual.
2. Remove the epoxy-locking compound that fills the pockets by drilling holes in 
the pockets, and removing any material that would prevent the bushing from 
being removed.
 Figure 2-22:       Bushing Lock Removal
3. Turn the eccentric upside down on wood blocking high enough to allow the 
bushing to be lowered clear of the eccentric.1- Locking material 2- Eccentric bushing 3- Drilled holes in cored pockets
4- Cored pockets 5- Eccentric
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
50Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-23:       Eccentric Bushing Removal
4. Manufacture a round plate from 25 mm (1 in) thick steel with a diameter slightly 
smaller than the eccentric bore, that will be used to remove the bushing from 
the eccentric. The outside diameter of the plate must be smooth and tapered so 
it does not damage the eccentric bore.
5. Set the plate on the bottom of the bushing, ensuring that it does not contact the 
eccentric bore.
6. Apply force to the plate until the bushing comes free of the eccentric.
7. If force is not enough to remove the bushing, cut through the bushing wall using 
a heavy duty circular saw, as detailed in 2.18.2 “Main Shaft Removal” on 
page 54.
2.17.2     Eccentric Bushing Removal from the Main Shaft
2.17.3     Eccentric Bore Inspection 
Before installing a new eccentric bushing, inspect the eccentric bore for rough spots 
and then smooth them out. Measure the eccentric bore every 4 in from top to 
bottom, 60 degrees apart at each location. These measurements will indicate:
•  High spots in the bore
•  Whether the bore has worn to an oversize condition
•  Whether the bore has pulled in due to excessive heat6- Eccentric 7- Wooden timber 8- Steel plate
9- Wooden blocking 10- Eccentric bushing
51Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Contact FLSmidth to verify the bore measurements. High spots may be addressed by 
grinding them off the uneven bore. However, if the bore has pulled in to the point 
that hand grinding is not practical, the bore must be machined back to its original 
size. Machining is also required if the bore is worn out of its round shape. 
Contact FLSmidth prior to any machining.
2.17.4     Eccentric Bushing Installation
The eccentric bushing is designed to have a light interference fit in the eccentric bore. 
Note: A tight fit is the result of a pulled in or an out-of round eccentric bore. An 
improperly stored or shipped bushing may become out of round.
1. Clean and inspect the bushing.
2. Remove any scratches and burrs.
3. Thoroughly clean the pockets in the eccentric of any epoxy-locking compound.
4. Inspect the eccentric bore for scratches, nicks, and gouges.
5. Smooth out any upsets found.
6. Cool the bushing until it is 24°C (43°F) cooler than the eccentric.
7. Mark lines on both sides and the top of the bushing adjacent to the oil hole loca -
tions.
8. Mark additional lines for the two holes in the eccentric bore. 
9. Extend the marked lines to the top surfaces. These lines will be used to align the 
oil holes in the bushing and eccentric.
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
52Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-24:       Eccentric Bushing Alignment
10. Using two M16  ring bolts (supplied in the special tools package) in the top of the 
bushing, lift and center the bushing above the eccentric. 
11. With the oil hole lines and locking pockets aligned, quickly lower the bushing 
into the eccentric. While lowering the bushing, ensure that the top of the bush -
ing is flush with the top of the eccentric.
12. Verify that the oil passage holes in the bushing are aligned with the mating holes 
in the eccentric. Due to casting variations, this may not provide exact alignment 
of the locking pockets.
It is critical that the oil holes in the bushing match up with the oil holes in the 
eccentric.
13. Ensure that the eccentric and eccentric bushing have warmed to ambient tem -
perature (16° to 27°C [60° to 80°F] is desired). 
14. Mix the locking compound according to the manufacturer’s instructions, and fill 
each locking pocket to the top.1- Location for marking lines 2- Small oil hole 3- Oil holes
4- Eccentric Bushing 5- Large oil holes
53Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-25:       Eccentric Bushing Alignment Showing Epoxy Location
15. After the epoxy has fully cured, remove any excess locking compound by grind -
ing the compound flush with the top of the bushing and eccentric.
16. When a new eccentric bushing is installed, the power draw must be re-mea -
sured.
a.  Allow the crusher to run for eight hours.
b.  Record the closed side setting.
c.  Record the crusher drive motor power draw.
Note: The power draw peaks must never go above 110%.
2.18     Main Shaft Maintenance
2.18.1     Main Shaft Inspection
The maintenance log is required for this procedure. Refer to A.2 “Main Shaft 
Inspection Log” on page 61. 
Inspect the main shaft fit in the main frame hub annually and whenever the eccentric 
is removed from the crusher. This is especially important if the condition of the 
eccentric bushing is replaced.
1. Remove any bronze or lead by rubbing in a circular and horizontal directions 
with a fine emery cloth. 
2. Starting in the middle of the socket fit area, measure the outside diameter of 
the main shaft every 10.2 cm (4 in) from top to bottom, 60 degrees apart at each 
location. Record whether the measurements are acceptable in the maintenance 
log. Refer to A.2 “Main Shaft Inspection Log” on page 61.1- Ring bolts and washers 2- Bushing lock 3- Eccentric bushing 4- Eccentric
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
54Chapter 2: Maintenance
3. Contact FLSmidth to determine if the condition of the main shaft requires a 
replacement. Measure the clearance between the shaft and bore at the top of 
the hub with a feeler gauge.
a.  Measure the clearance at four points 90 degrees apart.
b.  Calculate the average clearance. The average clearance must not exceed 0.06 
mm.
c.  Record the measurements and average in the maintenance log. Refer to A.2 
“Main Shaft Inspection Log” on page 61.
d.  If there is excessive clearance at the top or the bottom, contact the FLSmidth 
customer service department immediately.
2.18.2     Main Shaft Removal
If the eccentric bushing is seized on the main shaft, extra effort is required to remove 
the eccentric assembly. Consult FLSmidth for suggested additional instructions. 
1. Using a heavy-duty circular saw and metal cutting blade, cut around the bushing 
wall at the longitudinal oil groove location. 
Note: Located on the inside of the bushing is a longitudinal oil groove that is cen -
tered on the large oil hole. The oil hole is visible from the outside of the bushing, 
and is vertically centered on the bushing.
2. Set the depth of the cut at 20 mm (0.75 in) .
Do not exceed a 25 mm (1 in) depth . It is critical to avoid damaging the main 
shaft. If the shaft is scored, it may need to be replaced.
3. Using a pry bar, spring the bushing open and off the main shaft.
2.18.3     Main Shaft Installation
The replacement of the main shaft requires a proper fit between the shaft and the 
main frame hub. Only an FLSmidth-trained technician may install a shaft. Contact the 
FLSmidth customer service department for assistance in replacing the shaft.
2.19     Head Stub and Ball Replacement
2.19.1     Head Stub and Ball Removal
1. Remove the two hex socket pipe plugs and two M24 socket head capscrews 
from the  recessed pocket of the head.
2. Place the head stub and ball on wood blocking. Refer to Figure 2-26 "Removing 
Head Stub and Ball" on page 55.
55Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Note: The blocking must be high enough to allow the stub and ball to just clear 
the bore in the head when they drop. If the stub and ball are allowed to drop 
through the lower head bushing, the bushing may be damaged.
3. Strike the stub and ball on one side and then on the other with a sledgehammer 
to drive them out of the interference fit in the head.
4. If the stub and ball do not move while hitting the side with the sledgehammer:
e.  Heat the head to a maximum of 65°C (149°F)  in the area. Continue striking the 
side of the stub and ball with the sledgehammer until they are removed.
 Figure 2-26:       Removing Head Stub and Ball
2.19.2     Head Stub and Ball Installation
1. Cool the replacement head stub and ball until they are 65°C (149°F)  cooler than 
the head.
Note: This will shrink it enough to be set in the head.
2. Measure the bore in the head and the head stub to verify enough shrinkage has 
occurred for installation.
3. Attach two M16  sto the bottom of the head stub and ball , and position the 
assembly above the head .
4. Quickly lower it into the head, engaging the dowels and ensuring that the head 
stub and ball are fully seated in the bore of the head. 1- Steel round bar 2- Area to be heated (if necessary) 3- Clearance
4- Head stub and ball 5- Blocking 6- Upper head bushing
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
56Chapter 2: Maintenance
 Figure 2-27:       Installing Head Stub and Ball
5. Verify that the head stub and ball have approximately 27.4 +/- 1 mm (1.1 +/- 
0.04 in)  penetration through the head . Take the measurement from the machine 
flat of the head to the machine flat of the stub and ball. Cool the head ball until it 
is 41°C (105°F) cooler than the head.
6. Install the head ball lifting plate on the head ball.
7. Lift the head ball, and lower it into the head. Engage the ball dowels with the 
dowel holes in the head.
8. Install the M24 socket head capscrews.
2.20     Bowl Adjustment Mechanism Replacement
Inspect the bowl adjustment mechanism when it is removed for other maintenance.
2.20.1     Bowl Adjustment Mechanism Removal
1. Remove the bowl assembly from the crusher following the instructions in 2.20.1 
“Bowl Adjustment Mechanism Removal” on page 56.
2. Remove the drive ring and pinion covers from the adjustment ring. Refer to the 
installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual .
3. Electrically isolate the HPU. 
4. De-pressurize the tramp, clamp, and clearing hydraulic circuits. Refer to the 
installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual. Verify that the tramp 
circuit pressure is zero, as indicated on the tramp circuit pressure transducer.
5. Unbolt the dust shell and remove it from the top of the adjustment ring.
6. Disconnect the proximity sensors at the hydraulic adjust motor assembly.
7. Remove the vibration sensors mounted on the adjustment ring.
57Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Chapter 2: Maintenance
Note: Be careful not to damage the cords as they are permanently secured to 
the sensors. 
8. Remove the adjustment ring assembly. Refer to Refer to the installation, opera -
tion, and maintenance (IOM) manual .
9. Inspect and lubricate the adjustment ring, clamping ring, and bowl threads. 
Refer to the installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
2.20.2     Bowl Adjustment Mechanism Installation
1. Lift the bowl adjustment mechanism using lifting lugs.
 Figure 2-28:       Lifting Hydraulic Adjustment Mechanism Assembly
2. Position the adjustment mechanism so one of the drives is 45 degrees from the 
countershaft box centerline and the main frame pins align with the main frame 
pin bushings in the adjustment ring.
3. Bolt the drive ring support brackets to the adjustment ring. If the drive ring 
retainers are attached, remove them.
4. Remove the pinion shields protecting the drive pinions.
5. Connect the hydraulic lines to the hydraulic adjust motors and brakes. Refer to 
the installation, operation, and maintenance (IOM) manual.
6. Install the drive ring. Refer to the installation, operation, and maintenance 
(IOM) manual .
2.21     Cleaning the Hydraulic System
The following signs are typical indications of the need to clean the hydraulic system:1- Hydraulic drive assembly 2- Pinion 3- Drive ring support
Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.
58Chapter 2: Maintenance
•  Frequently-plugged hydraulic oil filter
•  Plugged filter indication on the hydraulic oil filter
•  Emulsions
•  Contaminant buildup in the reservoir and on components within the hydraulic 
system
•  Irregular hydraulic circuit operation, including high oil temperatures
•  Poor oil condition, including dark color, cloudy, or mil ky appearance; rancid or 
burnt smell; or incorrect viscosity
1. At the remote push button panel, push the EMERGENCY STOP and the HYD. 
POWER UNIT CONTROL POWER buttons to turn the power control circuit off.
2. Lock out the electrical power to the hydraulic system following the site lockout 
policy.
3. Open both the tramp release and clamping system dump valves. Wait until the 
pressure in both systems is at zero, and then close both valves again.
4. Drain all the oil from the power unit reservoir. Oil in the release and clamping 
systems and their lines can be left in place when the reservoir is drained.
Note: Unless there is a serious oil contamination issue, the oil in the release and 
clamping systems, and their lines can be left in place.
5. Remove the round clean-out reservoir cover.
6. Clean the inside of the reservoir with a solvent, and then dry it with clean lint-
free rags.
7. Reinstall the strainer and then the reservoir cover.
8. Fill the reservoir with hydraulic oil. Refer to the installation, operation, and 
maintenance (IOM) manual.
9. Unlock and re-energize the hydraulic system.59Copyright © 2019 FLSmidth Inc. All rights reserved.  4/11/19
FLSmidth is constantly striving to improve its products and must therefore reserve the right to change designs, materials, specifications, and price without notice.Appendix A: Maintenance Log
